questions.text: False about Magnetic Resonance Cholangio-Pancreatography (MRCP) is:

choices.text: Contrast material must be injected in to ductal system
It evaluates both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.solution:
MRCP uses the fluid which is present in the biliary and pancreatic ducts as a contrast agent and does not require external contrast material administered into the ductal system.

It is a non invasive investigation for evaluating extrahepatic, intrahepatic bile duct and pancreatic duct. No interventions are performed under MRCP.

MRCP uses T2 weighed  MRI and it recognizes slow flowing or stationary fluid within ducts, which appear brighter relative to adjacent solid tissues.

MRCP can be used to evaluate various conditions of pancreatobiliary ductal system, examples:

  • Congenital anomalies of the cystic and hepatic ducts
  • Post-surgical biliary anatomy
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction
  • Choledocholithiasis
  • Biliary structures
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Pancreatic cystic lesions
  • Trauma to biliary system

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis.

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Azole antifungals are of two types:

  • Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Which is the most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP) is Escherichia coli.

It is commonly caused by an ascending urethral infection or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. Sexually transmissible infections and other urinary pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus faecalis may also be responsible.

The patient presents with fever, perineal pain, chills and rigor, and dysuria. Per rectal examination will reveal a tender, boggy prostate. Care should be taken to avoid aggressive palpation or prostatic massage as it can lead to bacterial dissemination and sepsis.

Urine examination and culture should be done. Urine examination reveals threads in urine.

Management:  

Patients with systemic signs of infection should be admitted for IV antibiotics, hydration, and monitoring of laboratory parameters.

Patients who have no signs of systemic infection, who can tolerate oral intake, and who have no urinary retention can be treated with oral antibiotics. Antibiotics are given for 2-6 weeks to ensure the eradication of the infection as antibiotics don't penetrate the prostate capsule easily. 

For outpatient therapy: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg oral every 12 hours or levofloxacin 500 mg OD or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole double-strength tablet oral every 12 hours can be used.

For hospitalized patients: Intravenous ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin with or without an aminoglycoside (gentamicin or tobramycin) or intravenous beta-lactam with or without an aminoglycoside. Gram-positive infections are treated with cephalosporins (cephalexin, cefazolin) or dicloxacillin and vancomycin.

questions.text: The following graph shows the recording of cervical dilatation against time. All of the following statements are true regarding the graph except:

choices.text: The preparatory division includes A,D in the graph
The dilatational division occupies the phase of E in the graph
In nulliparas the minimum normal rate of progression of phase B in the graph is 1.5 cm/hour
Protraction and arrest disorders are problems associated with phase B of the graph

questions.solution:
The phase B in the above graph corresponds to the active phase of labor, and in nulliparas, the minimum normal rate of progression is 1.2 cm/hour.

In the above graph:

  • A corresponds to latent phase of labor
  • B corresponds to active phase of labor
  • C corresponds to second stage of labor
  • D corresponds to acceleration phase
  • E corresponds to phase of maximum slope
  • F corresponds to deceleration phase

A scientific approach by Friedman (1954) described a characteristic sigmoid pattern for labor by graphing cervical dilatation against time.

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of labor

Preparatory division Dilatational division Pelvic division
Latent phase + acceleration phases The phase of maximum slope Deceleration phase + the second stage of labor

Little cervical dilatation

The most rapid rate of dilatation

 Cardinal fetal movements of cephalic presentation occur

Sedation and conduction analgesia can arrest this division

 Unaffected by sedation  --

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Aphthous ulcers, surrounded by a rim of erythematous mucosa, are the earliest lesions seen in a patient with Crohn's disease during endoscopy.

Crohn's colitis usually spares the rectum and is most severe in the ileocaecal region.

  • In early Crohn's disease, small, punched-out aphthous ulcers are often seen (the result of submucosal lymphoid follicle expansion).
  • In moderate disease, the aphthous ulcers coalesce into larger ulcers, which may take on the appearance of a star (stellate ulcers).
  • As disease severity increases, submucosal edema and injury can result in cobblestoning of the mucosa (option A) and eventually the formation of serpiginous ulcers, which are typical findings in Crohn's disease. 

Thorn-like extraluminal projections in barium studies are known as rose-thorn appearance, and are a typical sign of Crohn's disease. They represent deep penetrating linear ulcers or fissurings typically seen within stenosed terminal ileum with a thickened wall. (Options C and D)

questions.text: Which of the following is a mediator of opsonization?
questions.solution:
Opsonisation is mediated by C3b and its inactive iC3b

Complements :

  • The complement system is a collection of soluble proteins and membrane receptors that function mainly in host defense against microbes and in pathologic inﬂammatory reactions.
  • The system consists of more than 20 proteins, some of which are numbered C1 through C9
  • In the process of complement activation, several cleavage products of complement proteins are elaborated that cause increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, and opsonization.
  • The critical step in complement activation is the proteolysis of the third (and most abundant) component, C3.

Cleavage of C3 can occur by one of three pathways:

  • The classical pathway
  • The alternative pathway
  • The lectin pathway

Functions of complements :

  • C3a, C5a and  to a lesser extent C4a – Anaphylotoxins
  • C5a – Chemotaxis
  • C3b and inactive C3b – Opsonisation
  • C5b-9 – Membrane attack complex

questions.text: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to removal of which of the following ethmoidal cells?
questions.solution:
Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.

Option A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.

Option B: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinates.

Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.text: Parasite F test used in the diagnosis of malaria is done to detect the antigen ______
questions.solution:
Parasite F test:

  • It is based on the detection of Histidine rich protein -2 antigen produced by the asexual stages of P. falciparum expressed on the surface of red cells.
  • Dual antigen test – detects pLDH as well as HRP-2 antigen.

questions.text: True about breath holding spell is

choices.text: Occurs between 1 to 6 months of age

questions.solution:
Breath holding spells are typically initiated by a provocative event that causes anger, frustration causing child to cry.

  • Tonic – clonic seizures may occur if it lasts for more than aa few seconds
  • Recovery within seconds is followed by normal activity
  • Occur between 6 months to 5 years of age
  • Peaks at 2 years
  • Treatment – Reassurance

questions.text: Most common type of Multiple Sclerosis
questions.solution:
The most common type of MS is the relapsing type [RMS] (~90%)

About 2% of RMS progresses to secondary progressive MS [SPMS] and about 10% develop the type of primary progressive MS [PPMS]

Note: SPMS or even PPMS will occasionally experience relapses and remissions, although far less often than in RMS. The term progression is now reserved to describe neurological worsening that accumulates independently from disease activity.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought with complaints of sensitivity to light and profuse lacrimation. On inspection, the given finding is seen on her upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Spring catarrh or vernal keratoconjunctivitis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

It is a bilateral, seasonally recurrent, chronic conjunctivitis due to type I hypersensitivity allergic reaction to an external antigen. The antigen reacts with IgE, this stimulates mast cell degranulation leading to the release of histamine and other mediators of the allergic response.

Spring catarrh is one of the several forms of allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Treatment of ptosis caused by Horner’s syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Fasanella servat operation is done for cases of mild ptosis (1.5-2 mm) with retained levator palpabrae superioris muscle function as seen in Horner’s syndrome.

Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the loss of sympathetic supply to the muller's muscle of the lid and not due to levator muscle palsy. Fasanella servat operation is not done in patients with severe ptosis and poor levtaor function.

Option A:Levator resection is performed for moderate and severe grades of ptosis but with retained levator function. This operation is contraindicated in patients with poor levator function.

Option B: Frontalis sling also known as Brow suspension is done in patients with severe ptosis with poor or absent levator muscle function. Here, the lid is anchored to the frontalis muscle via a sling. 

Surgical treatment of various types of ptosis

Surgery Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Fasanella Servat < 2 mm -mild ptosis Horner Syndrome
Levator Resection – Anterior approach Any amount (but with retained levator function) Larger resection in ptosis
Levator resection – Conjunctival approach Any amount (but with retained levator function) Moderate resection in ptosis
Levator resection with aponeurotic reinsertion Any amount (but with retained levator function) Acquired ptosis
Frontalis suspension – Fascia lata >4 mm -severe ptosis Congenital ptosis – Marcus Gunn ptosis

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure __________
questions.solution:
The instrument given above is globe thermometer which is used to measure mean radiant temperature.

Other options : 

Option A - Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers are the most widely used instrument
  • Sling psychrometer/Whirling psychrometer:  It is used to measure the relative humidity

Option C - The air velocity is measured by an instrument called the "anemometer".

Option D - Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time. It contains both mercury and alcohol.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: The life cycle shown below is of:
questions.solution:
The life cycle shown is of Clonorchis sinensis. It causes clonorchiasis (Asian liver fluke infection). Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae).

The hosts for Clonorchis sinensis are:

  • Definitive host- humans
  • First intermediate host- snail 
  • Second intermediate host- fish

The immature flukes after excystation in the duodenum enter the biliary ducts and differentiate into adults.
The hermaphroditic adults produce eggs which are excreted in the feces. Upon reaching freshwater the eggs are ingested by snails, which are the first intermediate hosts. The eggs hatch within the gut and differentiate first into larvae (rediae) and then into many free-swimming cercariae. Cercariae encyst under the scales of certain freshwater fish which are then ingested by humans. Chronic clonorchiasis is strongly associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Other options:

Paragonimus westermani: The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue. The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Fasciola hepatica: It is transmitted via the ingestion of aquatic plants which act as carriers of the infection. Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation. Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.

Most infections are asymptomatic. Halzoun is a painful pharyngitis caused by the presence of adult flukes on the posterior pharyngeal wall after eating raw sheep liver. Obstructive jaundice can occur months or years later.

questions.text: A 20 years old female who had outstanding scholastic performance till about high school was noticed to become odd and eccentric in behavior compared to peers, would ruminate, had extremely brief psychotic episodes for 1 week. She had beliefs about supernatural powers and life after death. Her self-care has been adequate along with normal sleep and appetite. She might be suffering from
questions.solution:
Odd and eccentric behavior, magical thinking (supernatural powers) suggest Schizotypal personality disorder.

Option b: Episodes are extremely brief. Schizophrenia requires symptoms to be present for at least 1 month.

Option c and d: Outstanding scholastic performance and onset of symptoms only at 20 years rules out borderline intelligence and autism.

Cluster A personality disorder/ odd or eccentric group - core traits of being interpersonally distant and emotionally constricted.

It includes

  • Paranoid personalities are quick to feel slighted and jealous, carry grudges, and distrustful and suspicious i.e. expect to be exploited and harmed by others.
  • Schizoid personalities prefer to be alone, detached, unemotional - lack friendships or close relationships with others and are indifferent to praise or criticism by others.
  • Schizotypal personalities display eccentric and odd beliefs, engage in odd and eccentric gestures and practices, and exhibit odd speech.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

questions.text: The structure not passing through the aortic opening of the diaphragm is:
questions.solution:
The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

questions.text: Monoclonal antibody to IL-5 is ______.
questions.solution:
Monoclonal antibody to IL-5 is mepolizumab.

IL-5 plays a pivotal role in eosinophilic inflammation and is also involved in eosinophil survival and priming.

Mepolizumab is approved in highly selected (eosinophilic phenotype) patients with severe asthma.

IL-5 monoclonal antibodies approved for asthma:

  • Mepolizumab
  • Reslizumab
  • Benralizumab

Some of the important monoclonal antibodies are listed below:

questions.text: Therapeutic doses of which of the following is unsafe during the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Therapeutic doses of iron, folic acid and Vitamin B12 are safe during pregnancy.
  • However, Vitamin A plays an important role in the differentiation of various tissues, particularly during reproduction and gestation by regulating gene expression hence a syndrome of severe congenital malformations may occur in infants of mothers who have consumed therapeutic doses (0.5-1.5 mg/kg) of (Vitamin A) oral 13-cis-retinoic acid (e.g., Accutane), generally taken for the treatment of acne or cancer, during the 1st trimester of pregnancy.
  • These malformations result in a high incidence (>20%) of spontaneous abortions and birth defects including characteristic craniofacial abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the above image is acanthosis nigricans.

Acanthosis nigricans is a darkening of the skin of the intertriginous areas. The hyperpigmentation is generally velvety with poorly defined borders and thickening of the skin. 

It can be grossly classified into benign and malignant.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is associated with obesity or insulin resistance. It is common and mild in nature. 

Malignant acanthosis nigricans has a rapid onset and is characterized by symmetrical, hyperpigmented, rugose, velvety plaques. It affects the axillae and flexures, nape of the neck, and mucosal surfaces. If it occurs de novo and is associated with weight loss, malignancy should be suspected. Generalized pruritus and skin changes of tripe palms (acanthosis palmaris) are also associated with malignancy. 

In malignancy, tumor cells are believed to produce transforming growth factor-alpha or cytokines that activate insulin-like growth factors. Leser-Trelat sign is the presence of prominent acrochordon-like papillamatosis arising from the plaques. 

The most common site of neoplasm is the gastrointestinal tract. 

Acanthosis nigricans can only be treated by treating the underlying disease. In addition, treatment specific to acanthosis nigricans is done for aesthetic reasons. 

Medications like keratolytics, topical vitamin D, and melatonin can be used. Procedures like laser, dermabrasion, and chemical peels are also available. 

Other options: 

Option A - Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy with characteristic skin findings such as Gottron papules, Heliotrope rash, shawl sign, and V sign. The following image shows Gottron papules.

 

Option C - Pityriasis rosea is a papulosquamous disorder that is characterized by a herald patch followed by scaly oval patches on the trunk in a Christmas tree appearance. The following image shows the lesions of Pityriasis rosea. 

 

Option D - Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches on the face. The following image shows the pigmentation of melasma. 

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

tracts

pancreatic islet cell adenoma

questions.text: Identify the correct match
questions.solution:
McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia - A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway.

Other options:

  • Trotter’s method is used to control epistaxis. The patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth.
  • Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).
  • Pringle maneuver is used for minimizing blood loss during hepatic surgery by clamping the vascular pedicle (free margin of lesser omentum).

questions.text: Indications of myomectomy are all except:
questions.solution:
Indications of myomectomy are

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size >12weeks, woman desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapidly growing myoma during follow-up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid.

Red degeneration is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy and usually managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics.

questions.text: Which of the following implant materials has the best corrosion resistance?
questions.solution:
Titanium implants have the best resistance to corrosion.

The three types of metallic implants used:

  • Stainless steel alloy: Iron-based, contains around 18% chromium.
  • Cobalt-based alloy: Composed of cobalt, chromium, molybdenum, and nickel.
  • Titanium-based alloys: Made of 90% titanium. Very strong and highly resistant to corrosion.

Nonmetallic implants usually are made-up of plastic materials. Polyethylene, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) and silicones are the commonly used nonmetallicimplants.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about congenital syphilis?

choices.text: It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration
Infection of fetus most commonly occurs in the 1st trimester
Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication
Chances of transmission are lower if mother has late syphilis

questions.solution:
The chances of transmission of syphilis during pregnancy is highest after 6th month of gestation. It does not occur before the 4th month.

It is routine to test the mother for syphilis in antenatal clinics during her first visit. The chance of infection of the fetus is higher when the mother is suffering from early (primary or secondary) syphilis and are lower in case of late syphilis. Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication of congenital syphilis. It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and smoky, cola-colored urine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. He is found to have periorbital edema and mild hypertension. Urine examination shows dysmorphic red cells and red cell casts in the urine with mild proteinuria. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement. The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  • Formation of immune complexes
  • Deposition of immune complexes
  • Inflammation and tissue injury

This results in various manifestations like vasculitis, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction
  • Farmer’s lung
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Type II lepra reaction
  • Henoch–Schonlein purpura

The image given below shows the mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: According to the national framework for malaria elimination in India, states were categorized based on ______.
questions.solution:
The annual parasite index (API) is used to categorize states/union territories under the national framework for malaria elimination in India.

The national framework for malaria elimination in India was launched in February 2016 with the following goals:

  • Eliminate malaria throughout the entire country by 2030
  • Maintain malaria-free status in areas where transmission has been interrupted and prevent re-introduction

It uses the annual parasite index to classify states/union territories into four categories.

  • Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/union territories with zero cases
  • Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/union territories with all their districts having API <1
  • Category 2 (pre-elimination phase): States/union territories with API <1, but some of their districts having API≥1
  • Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States/union territories with API≥1

API is calculated by the formula: confirmed cases during one year X 1000 / population under surveillance.

Regions with API≥ 2 are considered as high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Other options:

Option B: Slide positivity rate is used to describe the percentage of slides positive for the malarial parasite. The type of species is not taken into account.

Option C: Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum species. 

Option D: Annual blood examination rate is derived by the formula - number of slides examined X 100/ Population. It is considered an index of operational efficiency.

 

 

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: Drug that can prevent the cardiac remodeling in patients with chronic heart failure is
questions.solution:
Eplerenone is an aldosterone antagonist. Aldosterone antagonists prevent cardiac remodeling. It inhibits the direct deleterious effects of aldosterone on cardiac remodeling and also benefits indirectly by its action on extracellular volume and cardiac workload.

Treatment of CHF:

  • Relief of congestive symptoms and restoration of cardiac performance
    • Inotropic drugs (digoxin, dobutamine, amrinone)
    • Diuretics (Furosemide, Thiazides)
    • RAAS inhibitors (ACE inhibitors/ ARBs)
    • Vasodilators-  (hydralazine, nitrate, nitroprusside)
    • Beta blockers (metoprolol, carvedilol)
  • Reversal of disease progression - These drugs prevent ventricular remodelling
    • ACE inhibitors / ARBS
    • Beta blockers
    • Aldosterone antagonists (spironolactone, eplerenone)
    • Combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate has also shown to reduce mortality in CHF.

questions.text: The predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I is
questions.solution:
Growth hormone acts on the liver to form small proteins called “somatomedins”

  • Somatomedins increases bone growth in all aspect
  • Effects are similar to insulin, hence referred to as insulin-like growth factor (IGF).
  • Four types available:
    • Most important is somatomedin C, specifically referred to as “insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1)
    • Binds to carrier protein in blood
    • Hence, longer duration of action than growth hormone.
    • Half-life - about 20 Hrs (compared to growth hormone - 20 mins)
    • Blood concentration of IGF-1, follows the levels of growth hormone.
  • Growth effects of GH are mostly attributed to somatomedin (rather than its direct effect on bones & peripheral tissues)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being evaluated for sudden onset of hypersecretory glaucoma, diarrhea, and cardiac failure. Further probing reveals that she had been purchasing groceries from a dealer who was recently arrested for food adulteration. What toxin is likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

questions.text: Difficulty in identifying known faces is termed as
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces that is not due to impaired visual acuity or level of consciousness.

Other options:

  • Anosognosia
    • It is the ‘lack of insight’ which usually manifests as an inability to perceive their own symptoms or denial of them or lack of concern for their current difficulties.
    • It is commonly associated with certain types of frontotemporal lobar dementia (FTD) and with traumatic brain injury (particularly to the right hemisphere).
  • Cotard syndrome is a condition in which an individual feels like they have lost all possessions and status, including their entire being and all internal organs.
  • Nihilism is a delusion of the nonexistence of the self or part of the self. It is also a philosophical doctrine of total rejection of established values or extreme skepticism regarding moral and value judgments.

Note: Nihilistic delusion is a delusional disorder where one believes that the world and everything related to it have ceased to exist.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common structure seen in all the sphingolipids?
questions.solution:
Ceramide = Sphingosine + Fatty acid

This is the basic structure found in all the sphingolipids.

Hence, ceramide is the common structure among all sphingolipids.

Glycerol is found in glycerolipids only → option a is excluded

N-acetylneuraminic acid (NANA) is found in gangliosides, not in all the sphingolipids → option c is excluded.

Phosphoryl choline is found only in sphingomyelin, not in all the sphingolipids → option d is excluded.

questions.text: Dent's disease is  characterized by all except ______________
questions.solution:
Dent’s disease is characterised by all except hyperphosphatemia.

  • Dent's disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by inactivating mutation in CLN5, a chloride transpoter expressed in endosomes of the proximal tubule (Dent disease 1) or OCRL gene mutation (Dent disease 2).
  • Features include nephrocalcinosis, hypercalciuria, hypophosphatemia and recurrent kidney stones and additional symptoms of mild intellectual disability, hypotonia and clouding of lens of eyes in dents disease 2.
  • The clinical diagnosis of Dent's disease is based on the presence of all three of the following criteria:
    • LMW proteinuria (elevation of urinary excretion of β2-microglobulin, Clara cell protein and/or RBP by at least 5-fold above the upper limit of normality)
    • Hypercalciuria (> 4 mg/kg in a 24 h-hour collection or > 0.25 mg Ca2+ per mg creatinine on a spot sample)
    • At least one of the following: nephrocalcinosis, kidney stones, hematuria, hypophosphataemia, or renal insufficiency.
  • The clinical diagnosis is supported by a history of X-linked inheritance of renal Fanconi syndrome and/or nephrolithiasis.
  • The identification of mutation in either CLCN5 or OCRL1 confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: During the autopsy of a patient, the liver was found to have the following appearance. What condition did the patient likely suffer from?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a mottled appearance of the liver, which is known as nutmeg liver. It is seen due to chronic passive venous congestion in the liver (congestive hepatopathy), usually due to congestive heart failure.

It is usually seen in patients with chronic right-sided cardiac lesions leading to right-sided heart failure. This causes the blood to be dumped back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins. This leads to increased pressure in the sublobular branches of the hepatic veins.

In this condition, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed because of cell death. They are accentuated against the surrounding zones of the uncongested tan-colored liver. This appearance is called nutmeg liver due to its close resemblance with the cut surface of the nutmeg seed, as shown below.

Microscopic examination reveals:

  • Centrilobular hemorrhages
  • Hemosiderin-laden macrophages
  • Variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis

Congestion in the centrilobular vein with necrosis of the surrounding hepatocytes can be seen in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with reference to the development of the brain?

choices.text: The superior cerebellar peduncles develops from the metencephalon
The rhombomeres 2 and 3 contains the motor nucleus of the facial nerve
The cervical flexure is present between the metencephalic part of the rhombencephalon and the spinal cord
The pontine flexure is directed ventrally between the metencephalon and myelencephalon

questions.solution:
During the development of the brain, the pontine flexure is present between the metencephalon and myelencephalon parts, of the rhombencephalon, and is directed ventrally.

The developing brain consists of three major divisions: prosencephalon (forebrain), mesencephalon (midbrain), and rhombencephalon (hindbrain).

  • The prosencephalon gives rise to the telencephalon, diencephalon 1 (D1) and diencephalon 2 (D2), which has three subdivisions.
  • The mesencephalon is subdivided into mesencephalon 1 (M1) and mesencephalon 2 (M2).
  • The rhombencephalon is subdivided into the isthmusrhombencephali and rhombomeres 1–8.

The following table shows derivatives of the cerebral regions from caudal to rostral

2.     Metencephalon

Superior medullary velum

Superior cerebellar peduncles

Cerebral peduncles

Note: Newer studies oppose the older model of brain development and suggest that instead of 3 anatomical divisions, it is better to divide it into anterior and posterior divisions. 

The pattern of the distribution of the motor nuclei associated with the rhombomeres is as follows:

Division of the rhombomeres Associated motor nuclei
Rhombomere 1 Trochlear nucleus
Rhombomeres 2 and 3 Trigeminal nucleus
Rhombomeres 4 and 5 Facial nucleus
Rhombomere 5 Abducens nucleus
Rhombomeres 6 and 7 Glossopharyngeal nucleus
Rhombomeres 7 and 8 Vagal, accessory, and hypoglossal nuclei

Flexures of the developing brain:

The prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon are initially arranged craniocaudally, which is altered by the formation of various flexures as below:

  • Cervical flexure: Present between the myelencephalic part of the rhombencephalon and the spinal cord.
  • Cephalic flexure: Also known as mesencephalic flexure. It is present in the region of midbrain and is concave ventrally.
  • Pontine flexure: It is present between the metencephalon and myelencephalon
  • Telencephalic flexure: It occurs between the telencephalon and the diencephalon.

questions.text: An anxious mother has brought a 4-month-old baby with complaints that the baby is not feeding well and is excessively sleepy all the time. Clinical examination reveals jaundice and hypotonia. His picture is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows a child with a protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and edematous facies. Also, the infant is sluggish, has jaundice, feeding difficulties, and hypotonia, all of which suggests a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia- early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation- usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular- slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory- macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Haematological- macrocytic anaemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system- hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence

questions.text: A patient undergoing withdrawal from which of the following drugs is least likely to experience suicidal thoughts?
questions.solution:
Withdrawal symptoms do not occur with hallucinogens such as LSD. Withdrawal symptoms appear when the drug abuse leads to physical dependence.

Drugs that cause significant withdrawal symptoms:

  • Alcohol
  • Opioids
  • Cocaine
  • Nicotine
  • Barbiturates
  • BZD

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.

Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman was diagnosed with melanoma. Sentinel lymph node biopsy showed malignant cells.  Which among the following is a recombinant interleukin-2 preparation approved for use in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of metastatic melanoma. The recombinant interleukin-2 (IL-2) preparation that is approved for use in metastatic melanoma is aldesleukin. It acts as an IL-2 agonist and is also approved for use in metastatic renal cell cancer.

Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin made from the recombinant combination of IL-2 and the catalytically active fragment of diphtheria toxin. It is approved for use in cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

Imatinib and nilotinib are a BCR/ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed and the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are suggestive of endodermal sinus tumors. It is also known as yolk sac tumor.

The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

It is the second most common malignant tumor of germ cell origin. It is a unilateral tumor usually affecting children or young women.

questions.text: Excess ammonia reduces which of the following substrates of the Krebs cycle?
questions.solution:
Excess ammonia results in depletion of levels of alpha-ketoglutarate.

This happens because excess ammonia reacts with alpha-ketoglutarate to form glutamate, mainly in the CNS.

questions.text: Causative organism for black piedra is ______
questions.solution:
Piedraia hortae is the causative organism for black piedra. White piedra is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.

Piedra is a fungal infection of the hair characterized by the presence of firm, irregular nodules along the hair shaft. The nodules consist of fungal elements that are cemented together on the hair.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and poor feeding after an episode of URTI. You suspect this as acute suppurative otitis media due to an eustachian tube defect. Which is the most accurate test to detect this?
questions.solution:
Tympanometry is the most accurate test to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction. It is an objective measure of ET function and does not rely on patient cooperation.

In this test, the movement of TM is visualized to the variation in external canal pressure. The disadvantage is middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. 

This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side.

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV.

 

Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with reference to the Couinaud's liver segments?

choices.text: It is classified based on the distribution of hepatic arteries in the parenchyma
The left lobe of the liver includes segments I, II, and III
Segment IV corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver
The right lobe of the liver includes segments V, VI, VII, and VIII

questions.solution:
The right lobe of the liver includes Couinaud’s segments V, VI, VII, and VIII.

  • The right anterior sector is formed by segments V and VIII
  • The right posterior sector is formed by segments VI and VII

Other options:

  • Option a: The classification of the liver segments based on the Couinaud’s system is based on the distribution of the portal venous system in the parenchyma.
  • Option b: The left lobe of the liver includes segments II, III (Left lateral sectors) and segment IV (quadrate lobe)
  • Option c: The segment I is represented by the caudate lobe of the liver, whereas segment IV is represented by the quadrate lobe.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: Which of the following diseases shows a hot spot on bone scan?
questions.solution:
Pagets disease shows hot spot on bone scan.

Bone Scan

Causes of the hot spot on bone scan: Causes of the cold spot on bone scan:

Infection (osteomyelitis)

Bone tumors, Fibrous dysplasia, metastases

Trauma; fracture healing

Avascular necrosis and Perthe's disease

Paget’s disease

Hyperparathyroidism

Multiple myeloma

Fibrous cortical defect

Pseudoarthrosis

questions.text: The following hysterosalpingogram indicates
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hysterosalpingogram showing the contrast dye filling an irregulary shaped edometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance. Hence, it is Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography can be performed alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

The above image is a hysteroscopic image of intrauterine adhesions found with Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in
questions.solution:
Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) in central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is called 100-day glaucoma.

NVG is intractable glaucoma which results due to neovascularization involving the angle of the anterior chamber.

Neovascularization develops following retinal ischaemia as in:

  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • Central retinal vein occlusion
  • Sickle-cell retinopathy
  • Eales’ disease
  • Rare causes: Intraocular tumours, longstanding retinal detachment


Patients with central retinal vein occlusion are at risk for what is termed 100-day glaucoma. In CRVO, retinal ischemia of greater than 10 disc diameters indicates significant risk for NVG.

Eighty percent of patients with central retinal vein occlusion with NVG developed the disease in the first 4 months after the initial occlusion. Therefore, clinicians should follow patients every month in the first 6 months to evaluate the iris and angle.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments can be used for submucosal resection operation to remove bone or cartilage?
questions.solution:
Image B shows Luc’s forceps, which is used in submucosal resection to remove either bone or cartilage.

Other uses:

  • Caldwell–Luc operation (to remove mucosa)
  • Polypectomy (to grasp and avulse polyp)
  • Take biopsy from the nose or throat.

Other images:

  • Image A:  It shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.
  • Image C: Image is of Tilley–Lichtwiz trocar and cannula, used for the puncture of the lateral wall of inferior meatus, at a point 1.5–2.0 cm from anterior end of inferior turbinate and near the attachment of concha with lateral wall.
  • Image D: The instrument is Rose’s sinus douching cannula used in irrigation of maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell–Luc operation. Direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
The median lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae.

Uvula vesicae is an elevation in the mucous membrane of the urinary bladder, behind the internal urethral orifice. It is often enlarged in benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.text: All the following are features of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia except

choices.text: Restrictive changes in pulmonary function test

questions.solution:
•  Males are predominantly affected (4:1) in tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical Pulmonary eosinophilia:

  • It is seen in persons infected with lymph node dwelling filarial species
  • Males are predominantly affected (4:1)
  • Nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough
  • Weight loss, low grade fever, adenopathy
  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities, increased bronchovascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Antifilarial antibody titres
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in lungs and hence not found in blood
  • Treatment: Diethyl carbamazine

questions.text: A positive Stallworthy sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Stallworthy’s sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign and is suggestive of low-lying placenta, especially posteriorly.

 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of dry cough and dyspnea on exertion. On evaluation, the following chest X-ray was obtained. Which of the following is not true about the suspected condition?

choices.text: Most common hematological problem is lymphopenia
The Kviem-Siltzbach procedure is a specific diagnostic test
Panda sign seen in Chest X ray

questions.solution:
• The above chest X-ray illustrates bilateral hilar adenopathy. The history and chest X-ray suggest a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
  • With regard to sarcoidosis, the panda sign is seen in gallium 67 nuclear scan.
  • In chest X ray , the signs are :
    • Lambda sign
    • 1-2-3 sign/Garland sign
  • HRCT
    • Galaxy sign
  • Gallium 67 scan
    • Panda sign
    • The Kviem-Siltzbach procedure is a specific diagnostic test for sarcoidosis. Not used clinically now.
    • Elevated levels of ACE are reported in 60% of patients with acute disease and only 20% of patients with chronic disease
      • The most common hematologic problem is lymphopenia, which is a reflection of the sequestration of the lymphocytes into the areas of inflammation.

questions.text: In order to effectively prevent endemic goiter, what is the recommended iodine content in salt at the consumer level?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of iodine content in salt is 15 ppm at the consumer level and 30 ppm at the production level.

The iodization of salt is used as a prophylactic measure against endemic goiter. In India, the level of iodization is fixed under the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act.

questions.text: What is the suspected cause preceding the observed effect an example of?
questions.solution:
Temporality refers to the condition when the suspected cause precedes the observed effect. It is a part of Hill’s criteria for causal association.

Related Pearl: Hill's Criteria for Causal Association

  • It is also called Bradford Hill criteria.
  • It was established in 1965 by English epidemiologist, Sir Austin Bradford Hill.

Criteria

Brief Description

Temporality

Suspected cause precedes observed effect.

Strength

Larger the relative risk, the more likely it is causal.

Consistency

If the association is observed repeatedly under the same or various conditions, then more likely it is causation.

Specificity

When exposure is associated with a specific outcome only, then it is more likely to be causal.

Plausibility

A biologically plausible mechanism between cause and effect can be support for causation.

Coherence

A causal conclusion should not seriously conflict with the present substantive knowledge of the outcome.

Analogy

Other established cause-effect relationships may be used in analogies to support this causal relationship.

Gradient

It is called dose-response or response curve. It refers to the existence of an exposure-response relationship.

Experiment

To check if the condition can be or has been changed, weakened or prevented by experimental approach.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
The testes do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis.

Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to the deposition of iron in the testis. It is due to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic.

Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs in the decreasing order of severity:

  1. Liver
  2. Pancreas
  3. Myocardium
  4. Pituitary gland
  5. Adrenal gland
  6. Thyroid
  7. Parathyroid gland
  8. Joints
  9. Skin

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in

choices.text: Slow filling at end of diastole

questions.solution: 'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating).

Frey’s syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops after parotid surgery. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers crossed along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the parotid region.

Clinical features are due to the result of salivary stimulation (by the smell or taste of food) leading to the sweating and flushing of the periauricular region on the involved side of the face. A starch iodine test is used for diagnosis.

Treatment ranges from antiperspirants (in mild cases) to tympanic neurectomy or botulinum toxin injection (in severe cases). It can be prevented by incorporating careful extracapsular dissection and closure of the superficial musculoaponeurotic layer during parotidectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Facial nerve is the 7th cranial nerve that supplies the muscles of the face, and results in facial paralysis if injured during parotidectomy

Option B: Oculomotor is the 3rd cranial nerve which supplies the extraocular muscles. If injured during ophthalmic surgeries, it results in ocular paralysis and the eye pointing down and out.

Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve is the 9th cranial nerve and its injury causes loss of taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. 

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text: Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL)  is caused by mutations in _____________
questions.solution:
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is caused by a mutation in the NOTCH 3 gene on chromosome19.

  • CADASIL is characterized by vasculopathy involving small arteries, arterioles & capillaries (predominantly in the brain). This is because Notch-3 protein is preferentially expressed in vascular smooth muscle cells & capillary pericytes.
  • CADASIL usually presents clinically as
    • Migraine with aura 
    • TIAs / Ischemic Stroke (Important cause of stroke in young)
    • Cognitive impairment / progressive dementia
    • Neuropsychiatric disturbances 
  • MRI is the preferred neuroimaging modality and usually reveals extensive subcortical white matter changes (lacunar infarcts) often including the anterior temporal lobes.
  • Diagnosis can be absolutely confirmed by 
    • Confirming NOTCH3 gene mutation
    • Skin biopsy to demonstrate vasculopathy by deposition of the misfolded Notch-3 protein [Granular osmiophilic material (GOM)]

questions.text: Which of the following is false about medullary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) does not take up radioactive iodine as MTC is TSH-independent.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular (C cells) derived from the neural crest. Histological analysis shows characteristic amyloid stroma. High levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen are produced by many medullary tumors. It also secretes 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin) or prostaglandin which may be a reason for diarrhea in 30% of cases. 20% are familial (multicentric and bilateral) and seen in younger ages. 80% sporadic (originate in one lobe) and is seen in the 6th decade. It is diagnosed by FNAC.

Treatment includes total thyroidectomy plus elective dissection of the central neck nodes plus or minus ipsilateral modified radical neck dissection (if neck node positive). If nodal metastasis cure is unlikely, the gross disease should be removed.

Related Pearl: Secretion of medullary thyroid tumors

Medullary thyroid tumor secrete the following:

  • Calcitonin
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Calcitonin gene–related peptide
  • Histaminadases
  • Prostaglandins E 2 and F 2 α
  • Serotonin

Calcitonin and serotonins are responsible for diarrhea in MTC.

questions.text: Which of the following lipoprotein contains the highest proportion of phospholipids?
questions.solution:
HDL lipoprotein has highest proportion of phospholipids compared to other lipoproteins.

Lipoproteins –Source and composition :

C-I, C-II, C-III, E

  • Triglyceride content is maximum in chylomicron
  • Phospholipid and protein content is maximum in HDL
  • Cholesterol content is maximum in LDL
  • Chylomicron is the transporter of dietary (exogenous) triglycerides; It is the lipoprotein with least electrophoretic mobility.
  • VLDL is the transporter of endogenous triglycerides from liver to peripheral tissues.
  • HDL is the mediator of reverse cholesterol transport from peripheral tissues to liver.
  • LDL receptor is a Clathrin-coated glycoprotein receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of the disease shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The images shows zebra pattern that is seen in Fabry's disease, which causes nephrotic syndrome (not nephritic syndrome).

Fabry's disease 

  • X-linked recessive disorder of globotriaosylceramide metabolism secondary to deficient lyososmal alpha galactosidase A activity resulting in excessive intracellular storage of globotriaosylceramide 
  • Classically it presents in childhood with acroparathesias, angiokeratoma, and hypohydrosis
  • Over time patients develop restrictive cardiomyopahty 
  • Renal biopsy reveals enlarged glomerular visceral epithelial cells packed with small clear vacuoles containing globotriaosylceramide. These vacuoles are arranged in parallel arrays known as zebra bodies which can be easily seen on electron microscopy
  • On urine analysis, oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light are seen known as maltese cross.
  • Treatment is recombinant alpha galactosidase A.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease started receiving dialysis. Which of his neurological complications can be reversed?
questions.solution:
Uremic encephalopathy in chronic kidney disease is reversible by dialysis.

Uremic encephalopathy occurs due to the aggregation of uremic toxins which in turn damages the neurons. It is seen in chronic kidney disease.

Symptoms begin with difficulty in concentrating and can progress to lethargy, confusion, seizure, cognitive impairment, and coma. Physical findings may include altered mental status, weakness, and asterixis. These findings improve with dialysis.

Electroencephalogram in uremic encephalopathy shows triphasic waves. 

Neurologic complications, which can manifest with advanced CKD and do not improve with dialysis therapy include -

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Restless leg syndrome (15-20%)

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has been admitted for a thorough evaluation following a history of right-sided weakness that resolved by the time she reached the hospital 2 hours after the onset. MRI of the brain reveals no signal changes. During rounds the next morning, the resident is asked about the patient's ABCD2 score. What does this score measure?
questions.solution:
Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as an episode of stroke symptoms that last <24 hours, which is the likely diagnosis according to the clinical scenario. The ABCD2 Score is used to measure the risk of stroke in a patient following TIA.

TIAs occur due to an embolic clot to the brain or a thrombosis within an intra-cranial vessel similar to what happens in an ischemic stroke, but in TIA, the vessel lumen opens up spontaneously leading to resolution of the neurologic symptoms. The risk of developing a stroke following a TIA is high especially during the first few hours-days, and hence patients are usually admitted to the hospital and started on dual anticoagulation with aspirin + clopidogrel, which has been found to prevent stroke following TIA. Thrombolysis is not indicated in TIA but is indicated in early stroke occurring following TIA.

Other options:

Option B: The CHA2DS2 VASc Score is to assess the risk for embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Based on the risk determined, the need for anticoagulation is decided.

Option C: The risk for developing pulmonary embolism is based on the Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria (PERC) scoring systems.

Option D: The severity of sub-arachnoid hemorrhage according on the clinical status of the patient at the time of presentation is based on the Hunt and Hess Score. It is used to predict the clinical outcome of the patient, ie, higher score indicates poorer outcome.

Related Pearl: ABCD2 Score

The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by ABCD2 score:

SBP>140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1
Clinical symptoms:
  • Unilateral weakness

  • Speech disturbances without weakness

Duration:
  • >60 minutes

  • 10 - 59 minutes

Diabetes 1
Total score Sum each score
ABCD2 Score Total 3-months Rate of stroke (%)

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
