Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A?
questions.solution:
Aspartate and glutamate are responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A and B of fibrinogen.

The negative charges contribute to the solubility of fibrinogen in plasma and importantly also serve to prevent aggregation by causing electrostatic repulsion between fibrinogen molecules.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella?
questions.solution:
Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

Rubella (German measles)

  • Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks
  • Rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post infectious thrombocytopenia
  • Most serious complication: Encephalitis
  • Vaccination: 27/3 live attenuated

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects.
  • The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term “blueberry muffin syndrome.”

Expanded rubella syndrome:

  • Some babies present with several other features like hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions constituting the expanded rubella syndrome. 
  • This term also refers to a baby with metastatic neuroblastoma.

 

Note: Rubella has been reclassified into the family of Matonaviridae in 2020. This is an MCQ from NEET 2019, hence the best answer out of the given options would be Togaviridae.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Which of the following is the best treatment for the relapse of immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Splenectomy is the treatment of choice in a case of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) relapse after first line therapy with glucocorticoids. The relapse usually occurs once they are tapered. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (pneumococcus, meningococcus, H. influenzae) is advised before splenectomy is performed.

It is important to note that in some patients ITP resolves by itself, and observation along with intermittent IV immunoglobulins and anti - Rh(D) administration or administration of a thrombopoietin receptor agonist (eltrombopag, romiplostim) can be a viable option before splenectomy is considered.

The treatment of ITP is as follows:

  Clinical features Management

1.   

Minor bleeding manifestations (and/or)

Platelet count > 5000/ μL

Prednisone (OR)

Anti-D immunoglobulin therapy - effective only in Rh-positive patients (OR)

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

2.  

Severe ITP (any of the following):

  • Significant GI / intracranial bleeding
  • Platelet count < 5000/μL
  • Signs of impending bleeding (retinal or large oral mucosal bleeds)

Platelet transfusion (AND)

High-dose glucocorticoids (AND)

IVIG / Anti-D immunoglobulins + Rituximab
3.   Relapse after first-line therapy Splenectomy
4.    Unresponsive to all other therapy or relapse after splenectomy Thrombopoietin receptor agonists - romiplostim (subcutaneous), eltrombopag (oral)

ITP is an acquired disorder characterized by the immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP include systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), HIV-AIDS, and Hepatitis C.

ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal peripheral blood cells. Patients typically exhibit ecchymoses and petechiae or they may incidentally discover thrombocytopenia during a routine complete blood count. Rarely, life-threatening bleeding may occur. The presence of wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) and retinal hemorrhages can serve as warning signs of potentially life-threatening bleeding.

questions.text: Transdermal preparation of the following agent is available for use in Parkinson’s disease
questions.solution:
Rotigotine is a dopamine receptor agonist that is available as transdermal preparation for use in Parkinson’s disease.

Ropinirole and pramipexole are dopamine receptor agonists but are not available as transdermal preparation (options a and c).

Selegiline is a MAO-B inhibitor that is available as a transdermal patch but the transdermal preparation is indicated only in major depression (option d).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim?

choices.text: Duration of action is shorter than normal filgrastim
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
It should not be administered in sickle cell patients
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia

questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell anemia should not receive pegylated filgrastim as it can trigger a sickle cell crisis.

Filgrastim is a recombinant human G-CSF (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor). The pegylated forms of filgrastim, pegfilgrastim, and lipefilgrastim, are longer-acting forms. It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion only.

Indications of recombinant G-CSF:   

  • Severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
  • Severe neutropenia after high dose cancer chemotherapy
  • Severe congenital neutropenias
  • Neutropenia of patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine

Filgrastim is the first FDA-approved drug to treat patients with radiation-induced myelosuppression and to increase survival in such patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease developed secondary hyperparathyroidism for which he was treated appropriately, and was started on cinacalcet. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent.

It activates the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) in the parathyroids and blocks PTH secretion.

Cinacalcet is a type II calcimimetic agent , it means that it needs either Ca2+ or some other agonist to activate CaSR.

It is indicated for secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney disease and tumor of parathyroid gland.

Type I calcimimetic agents are those which can activate CaSR directly such as aminoglycoside and polylysine.

questions.text: When an ion on one side of a membrane cannot diffuse through the membrane, the distribution of other ions to which the membrane is permeable is affected in a predictable way. This is given by______
questions.solution:
Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a nondiffusible (protein) ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves (K+ and Cl-) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

  • Other options:
    • Nernst equation→ Calculation of equilibrium potential
    • Goldmann equation→ Calculation of diffusion potential when permeable to several different ions.
    • Henderson equation (Henderson – Hasselbach equation)→ Calculation of pH (acid-base balance).

questions.text: Waste sharps are taken from the autoclave after sterilization. Which waste treatment method would be employed next?
questions.solution:
Waste sharps are treated by mutilation or shredding. Shredding of waste is done to reduce the volume of waste and to increase the extent of contact.

Waste sharps are treated by autoclaving or dry heat sterilization, followed by mutilation or encapsulation.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

Microbiology, biotechnology, clinical laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, laboratory
cultures, stocks or specimens of microorganisms,
live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/plasma pyrolysis/ disposal in a secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Encapsulation- hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility.

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to?
questions.solution:
Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to cefotetan.

B. cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides, polymixin, first and second-generation cephalosporins (e.g. cefotetan) and carboxypenicillins. This antimicrobial resistance is mediated by efflux pumps, antimicrobial degradation, modifying enzymes or altered membrane functions.

B. cepacia is a Gram-negative bacillus which can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis.

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include meropenem, ceftazidime, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, piperacillin and temocillin.

questions.text: Sulfonylurea therapy, which is used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus, can also be useful in _________
questions.solution:
Sulfonylurea therapy is most useful in maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) and Type 2 DM.

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY):

  • Autosomal-dominant form of Type 2 diabetes mellitus affecting the younger population. Onset of diabetes is seen after 30 years but less than 50 years. It is associated with cystic kidneys.
  • Definite positive family history is present.
  • Impaired Glucose-induced insulin secretion.
  • MODY 3 is the most common form.
  • It is a monogenic diabetes i.e only one gene mutation is present.
    • Types 1,3,5: HNF Mutation – Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor
    • Type 2: Glucokinase mutation
    • Type 4: Insulin Promotor Factor-1 (IPF 1) mutation
  • There is insulinopenia with no antibodies and no insulin resistance.
  • The patient does not have obesity, hypertension or hyperlipidemia
  • Responds to sulfonylureas: OHA

Other options:

  • Option c: Wolfram syndrome is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder first evident in childhood. It consists of diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, optic atrophy, and deafness. Hence the acronym DIDMOAD. It is due to mutations in a gene named WFS I , which encodes a transmembrane protein localized in the endoplasmic reticulum. Cranial diabetes insipidus and sensorineural deafness develop during the second decade in 60-75% of patients.
  • Option d: Non obese LADA is slow onset type 1 diabetes.There will be complete damage to pancreas however the damage is slow and delayed but presents by 30 years as opposed to second decade in Type 1 diabetes. Patients with LADA should be prescribed insulin when the disease is diagnosed and treated like patients with type l diabetes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a history of acute breathlessness. On examination, there are soft heart sounds, JVP is increased, and an inspiratory decline in systolic blood pressure of 14 mmHg is observed. Which of the following statements about the condition is true?
questions.solution:
A 30-year-old male patient with acute breathlessness, falling BP, rising JVP, and soft heart sounds suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. In a cardiac tamponade, the ECG findings are low voltage and electrical alternans.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intrapericardial pressure, hence poor ventricular filling and fall in cardiac output.

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension
  • Pulsus paradoxus
  • Increased pulse rate
  • Prominent X descent
  • Muffled heart sound
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula)
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart or soft heart sound.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle

Treatment: Drainage of fluid

Other options:

  • Option A: Kussmaul sign is a rise or a lack of fall in JVP with inspiration.It is not seen in cardiac tamponade.
  • Option C: y descent is attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of limited or absent late diastolic filling of ventricle. Prominent x and y descent is seen in constrictive pericarditis.
  • Option D: The diastolic dip-and-plateau pattern, also known as a square root sign, is produced when early rapid diastolic inflow into the ventricle commences but is then abruptly halted by an opposing force. It is not seen in the cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the fracture shown in the image given below?

choices.text: Extension type is the most common type
Three point bony relationship is maintained
Malunion is the most common complication
Baumann’s angle is less than 80 degrees in this child

questions.solution:
The image shows an X-ray of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Normal Baumann’s angle is <80 degrees. In a supracondylar fracture, the Baumann's angle is >80 degrees, it suggests a varus displacement.

A supra-condylar fracture can be flexion type or extension type based on the distal fragment’s displacement. In extension type, the distal fragment is displaced posteriorly and is the commoner of the two types.

Malunion leading to gunstock deformity (cubitus varus) is the most common complication.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and shows minimal response to stimulation with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is ______
questions.solution:
The Apgar score in this baby is 4. It is calculated as:

Appearance: blue - score 0
Pulse: <100 beats/min - score 1
Grimace: with minimal response to stimulation - score 1
Activity: some flexion of the extremities - score 1
Respiratory effort: irregular - score 1

The total score is 4.

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Haemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Dr. Virginia Apgar MD, an American obstetrical anesthesiologist, is known for her invaluable invention of the Apgar score.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: The 'hold-on effect' is characteristically seen in
questions.solution:
The hold-on effect is seen in electrical injuries.

When the entry point is in the hand, the stronger flexor muscles of the arm go into spasm and cause a hold-on effect. Any object being held in the hand is involuntarily clenched and the current thus continues to flow.

questions.text: A patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are suggestive of small-vessel vasculitis. Investigating for ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) should be the next step to aid in diagnosis.

Small Vessel Vasculitis/ ANCA- associated Vasculitis

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis

(Wegener's granulomatosis)

 Microscopic Polyangiitis

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with Polyangiitis

(Churg Strauss syndrome)
Characterized by a triad of upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with glomerulonephritis. Characterized by necrotizing vasculitis with glomerulonephritis(pauci immune, crescentic) Characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs.
Nodular cavitary infiltrates in lungs showing necrotizing granulomas, and vasculitis on lung biopsy

Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, hemoptysis.

No URTI, No granulomas, No pulmonary nodules/cavities.

Mononeuritis multiplex - most common and characteristic.

Biopsy showing granulomas with eosinophilic infiltrates. 
C-ANCA + P-ANCA + P-ANCA +

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

questions.text: A patient's plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to _____
questions.solution:
Interferon-beta is secreted during infection due to viruses. 

Interferons are classified as cytokines. Interferons are non-toxic, non-antigenic and species-specific molecules. They are inactivated by proteases. They are stable at pH over 2-10, except INF-γ (labile at pH 2) and are non-dialysable and non-sedimentable.

There are three types of interferons - α, β and γ. IFN-α or leukocyte interferon is produced by leucocytes. It has antiviral activity, is immunoregulaotry and antiproliferative. IFN-β or fibroblast interferon is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It has antiviral activity and is thus increased in viral infections. It enhances MHC class 1 and NK cell activity. IFN-γ or immune interferon is produced by T-lymphocytes, NK cells . It activates macrophages, increases neutrophil function, enhances both MHC class 1 and class II expression and has anti-proliferative (anti-tumour) functions. 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient is suggested to undergo surgery for shoulder dislocation. Which of the following nerve block is recommended?
questions.solution:
Interscalene block is recommended for the surgical procedures involving the shoulder.

In interscalene block, the blockade occurs at the level of the superior and middle trunks of brachial plexus. It is performed by injecting a local anesthetic to the nerves of the brachial plexus as it passes through the groove between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Advantages of this block include rapid blockade of the shoulder region, and relatively easily palpable anatomical landmarks.

Disadvantages of this block include inadequate anesthesia in the distribution of the ulnar nerve, which makes this an unreliable block for operations involving the forearm and hand.

Image below depicts an interscalene block.

Other options:

Option A: Indications for a supraclavicular block are operations on the elbow, forearm, and hand. Blockade occurs at the distal trunk-proximal division level.

Image below depicts a supraclavicular block.

Option B: Infraclavicular block provides anesthesia to the arm and hand. Blockade occurs at the level of the cords.

Image below shows an infraclavicular block.

Option D: Indications for axillary block include surgery to the forearm and hand. Elbow procedures are also performed. Blockade occurs at the level of the terminal nerves. Although blockade of the musculocutaneous nerve is not always produced with this approach, it can be supplemented at the level of the axilla or at the elbow.

Image below depicts an axillary block.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus Blocks

 

Name of Block Level of Block Adequate Analgesia Seen at Limitations
Interscalene Superior and middle trunk Shoulder and upper arm. Most intense effect at C5-C7 dermatomes. Ulnar nerve (C8,T1) sparing
Supraclavicular Distal trunk and proximal division Elbow, forearm and hand Axillary and suprascapular nerve sparing; Pneumothorax, phrenic nerve palsy
Infraclavicular Cords Elbow, forearm and hand Intercostobrachial nerve sparing
Axillary Terminal nerves

Forearm and hand.

  • Most intense block in C7-T1 (Ulnar nerve) distribution
  • Least intense in C5-C6 dermatome
  • Most optimal for procedures from elbow to hand

 

 Musculocutaneous, axillary, medial cutaneous nerve branches sparing; Inadvertent intravascular injection

questions.text: Bilateral large retinoblastoma tumors indicate which of the following modalities in its initial treatment?
questions.solution:
• In retinoblastoma with large tumors, chemoreduction is done first followed by local management or enucleation/exenteration.
  • In chemoreduction, VEC regimen is used which includes vincristine, etoposide and carboplatin.
  • Extra-orbital extension usually indicates the need for exenteration.
  • Local management includes laser therapy and cryotherapy.
  • The following table gives the international classification of retinoblastoma.
Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favourable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favourable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata
5 Highly unfavorable
  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of retina
  • Vitreous seeding

questions.text: Money bag heart is seen in
questions.solution:
Money bag or leather bottle or a flask-shaped heart with relatively clear lung fields is seen in pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusions occur when excess fluid collects in the pericardial space (a normal pericardial sac contains approximately 30-50 mL of fluid).

Clinical presentation of pericardial effusions does not relate with the size of the effusion but rather with the speed at which the fluid has accumulated, as slow gradual accumulation allows the pericardium to stretch and accommodate much larger volumes of fluid. Regardless of volume, symptoms relate to impaired cardiac function due to intrapericardial pressure approximating intracardiac pressure leading to impaired filling of low-pressure chambers, particularly the right atrium. Dyspnoea and reduced exercise tolerance are early signs, progressing to severe impaired cardiac output and death in severe cases (e.g. cardiac tamponade).

Plain radiographic features :

  • A very small pericardial effusion can be occult on plain film
  • There can be globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (epicardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (pericardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the oreo cookie sign. 

Echocardiography is the method of choice to confirm the diagnosis, estimate the volume of fluid and most importantly assess the hemodynamic impact of the effusion.

Other options:

Option B: Egg on side appearance is seen in transposition of great vessels.

Option C: A boot-shaped heart is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot.

Option D: A figure of 3 sign is seen in coarctation of aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following Leopold’s maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus ?
questions.solution:
Leopold’s 1 i.e. fundal grip is used to assess fetal lie.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of the fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers.

Leopold’s maneuvers are done by four obstetric grips:

  1. Leopold’s 1 (Fundal grip): It assesses the uterine fundus. It helps the identification of fetal lie and fetal presentation. The breech gives the sensation of a large, nodular mass, whereas the head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
  2. Leopold’s 2 (Lateral grip): It assesses the presenting part's position. The second maneuver is accomplished as the palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted. On one side, a hard, resistant structure is felt-the back. On the other, numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt-the fetal extremities
  3. Leopold’s 3 (Pawlik's grip): It helps in the confirmation of fetal presentation. The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass, usually the head, will be felt.
  4. Leopold’s 4 (Pelvic grip): It assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: The anti-epileptic drug that acts by binding to SV2A synaptic vesicular protein is
questions.solution:
The anti-epileptic mechanism of action of levetiracetam appears to be due to its binding to SV2A synaptic vesicular protein. The exact mechanism on how the anti-epileptic action is exerted by binding to this receptor is unknown.

Options a and b: The exact mechanism of gabapentin and pregabalin is not known. Though they are GABA derivatives and designed as GABA agonists, they do not possess GABA mimetic activity in vitro. They may act through binding to specific type of Ca2+ channel subunit.

Option d: Zonisamide inhibits T type Ca2+ currents and also prolongs the inactivated state of Na+ channels.

questions.text: Which among the following is true about standard deviation?

choices.text: One standard deviation covers 95% of the values
It can be used only in normal distributions
It is a measure of central tendency

questions.solution:
The standard deviation (S.D) indicates the distribution of variables. It is a measure of dispersion.

It can be used in normal and skewed distributions, but it is particularly useful in normal distributions.

1 S.D covers 68% of the values. 2 S.D covers 95% of the values.

Measures of central tendency are mean, median and mode.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: Foot drop is caused by damage to:
questions.solution:
Foot drop is caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between great and second toes.

Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss
    • Anterior and lateral side of the leg
    • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe

Th image given below shows the course of common peroneal nerve.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the emergency department with the following lesions one hour after eating shrimp. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Cause is unknown in majority of cases

questions.solution:
The image shows multiple wheals in acute spontaneous urticaria. It is mediated by immunological and non-immunological mechanisms.

The primary mechanism of urticaria is mast cell degranulation triggered by immune (IgE-mediated) or non-immune (cytokines, complement) mechanisms, which cause the release of histamine. This increases vascular permeability and vasodilation.

It can be acute (<6 weeks) or chronic (>6 weeks). Acute spontaneous urticaria can be triggered: 

  • Hypersensitivity
  • Viral infections
  • Food allergy 
  • Drug allergy
  • Blood transfusions. 

However, the actual cause is unknown in nearly 60% of cases.

It is characterized by wheals, which are evanescent, well‐defined, pink, or pale swellings due to reversible dermal edema. It usually fades within hours without pigmentation. Wheals are usually very itchy and associated with a surrounding red flare when they arise.

They may occur anywhere on the body, including the scalp, palms, and soles, in variable numbers and sizes.

questions.text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother?
questions.solution:
Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers and should be taken for 10-14 days.

Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus. It is common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Clinical features of mastitis include:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Purulent nipple discharge
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Positive fluctuation test

A culture from nipple discharge or test-needle aspiration of the cellulitic area is done to confirm the organism and its antibiotic sensitivity. An ultrasonogram of the involved breast is done to exclude abscess. They are treated with antibiotics and adequate breast support. Choice of antibiotics in lactational mastitis:

  1. Dicloxacillin 500 mg 4 times a day is to be started empirically.
  2. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
  3. If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus species then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given for at least 10 days.

questions.text: Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery is a branch of
questions.solution:
Inferior pancreatico-duodenal artery is a branch of superior mesenteric artery.

On the other hand, the superior pancreatico-duodenal artery is a branch of the gastroduodenal artery. 

 

The main vessels supplying the duodenum are superior and inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.

questions.text: All are early morphological features of HIV lymphadenopathy except

choices.text: Impingement of germinal centers on interfollicular T cell areas

questions.solution:
Hyalinization of germinal centers is a late feature of HIV lymphadenopathy.

Biopsy specimens from enlarged lymph nodes :

In the early stages of HIV infection reveal:

  • Marked hyperplasia of B cell follicles.
  • The follicles are enlarged and often take on unusual, serpiginous shapes.
  • The mantle zones that surround the follicles are attenuated
  • The germinal centers impinge on interfollicular T cell areas.
  • This hyperplasia of B cells is the morphologic reﬂection of the polyclonal B-cell activation and hypergammaglobulinemia seen in HIV-infected individuals.

Late stages show :

With disease progression,

  • The frenzy of B-cell proliferation subsides and gives way to a pattern of severe lymphoid involution.
  • The lymph nodes are depleted of lymphocytes, and the organized network of follicular dendritic cells is disrupted.
  • Germinal centers may even become hyalinized
  • Viral burden in the nodes is reduced
  • These “burnt-out” lymph nodes are atrophic and small and may harbor numerous opportunistic pathogens, often within macrophages.
  • Because of profound immunosuppression, the inﬂammatory response to infections both in the lymph nodes and at extranodal sites may be sparse or atypical
  • In  the  empty-looking  lymph  nodes  and  in  other  organs, the presence of infectious agents may not be readily  apparent  without  special  stains. 
  • Lymphoid involution is not confined to the nodes
  • In later stages of AIDS, the spleen and thymus also are converted to “wastelands” that are virtually devoid of lymphocytes.

questions.text: An elderly patient with type II diabetes presents with altered sensorium. He has not been eating or drinking well for the past few weeks. There are no complaints of nausea or abdominal pain. His blood sugar level is 800 mg/dL. All of the following are true regarding this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). In this condition, the anion gap is normal or slightly elevated, hence, option c- high anion gap is seen is a false statement.

HHS arises due to a relative reduction in circulating insulin and decreased fluid intake. Low level of insulin leads to a hyperglycemic state by two main mechanisms- increased glucose production by the liver and decreased glucose uptake by the skeletal muscles. This hyperglycemia results in osmotic diuresis, leading to volume depletion which is further exacerbated due to inadequate fluid intake by the patient. Eventually, kidney function is affected, reducing the glucose excretion through urine. All these factors result in a hyperosmolar state. 

Commonly seen in the elderly, HHS is usually precipitated by stressful events such as myocardial infarction, stroke, recent surgery, or infection. Certain drugs like steroids, diuretics, and phenytoin have also been implicated.

Symptoms of HHS include weakness, polyuria, and decreased oral intake. Symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis like nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain are not usually seen. Hyperosmolarity can ultimately lead to altered sensorium, seizures, and coma. 

Laboratory investigations will show:

  • Blood sugar value >600 mg/dL
  • Sodium >135 meq/L
  • Moderately elevated creatinine due to prerenal azotemia
  • Osmolality between 330-380 mOsm/mL
  • pH >7.3
  • Normal to slightly elevated anion gap

A small anion gap metabolic acidosis may be seen, due to elevated lactic acid levels. Contrary to diabetic ketoacidosis, ketosis is usually not seen. 

Management includes treating the precipitating factor, fluid replacement, potassium supplementation based on serum potassium levels, and intravenous insulin. Once the patient can tolerate oral feeds, he can be started on subcutaneous insulin.

questions.text: A woman with BRCA1 gene mutation presented with lumps in both breasts and enlarged axillary lymphadenopathy. She gives a history of breast cancer in her sister. MRI and trucut biopsy done confirmed the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia
It is a slow growing tumor
Tamoxifen can be used in the treatment
Has poorer prognosis than invasive lobular carcinoma

questions.solution:
Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the cancer cells to the lymph nodes. 

Medullary carcinoma is a common type of breast cancer associated with BRCA1 gene mutation. Bilateral tumors are common when family history is present. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due to necrosis and hemorrhage. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative (ER/PR/Her-2 negative).

Histopathology consists of:

  • A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells
  • A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation

It has a better prognosis than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of oseltamivir and zanamivir?
questions.solution:
Oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors.

They competitively and reversibly interact with the enzyme sites to inhibit viral neuraminidase activity. This interferes with the release of the progeny from infected host cells, halting the spread of infection.

Early administration hastens the resolution of symptoms if given within 48 h of infection. Oseltamivir is given at a dose of 75 mg, BD for 5 days for the treatment of Influenza A and B.

For prophylaxis, it is given at a dose of 75mg, OD and continued for the duration of exposure.

questions.text:
The ABG findings of a patient are given below. Which of the following metabolic abnormality is present in this patient?

PaCO2: 35 mmHg

HCO3-: 30 mEq/L

pH: 7.50

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The given scenario reveals metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of ABG:

Step 1:

Value in the question Normal value Interpretation
pH = 7.50 (7.35 – 7.45) 7.4 Increased
paCO2 = 35  (35 – 45) 40 Normal
HCO3- = 30  (22 – 28) 25 Increased

The values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Step 2:

Calculating the respiratory compensation:

In metabolic alkalosis, Compensation formula is as follows:

∆ [HCO3-] = Increase in HCO3-, in above case is  = 30 - 25 = 5

So, compensatory increase of CO2 should be = 0.7 x 5 = 3.5

Applying the above, the compensation value of CO2 should lie between

40 + 3.5 = 43.5 or approx. 44

Taking +/- 3 into consideration,  Compensatory values of CO2 = 41 – 47

Step 3:

Since CO2 = 35 which is below the compensatory values, hence this is not compensated.

It suggests that there is a simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4:

Looking for anion gap:

Anion gap should be looked for only in cases of:

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Normal pH

Since the primary disorder is metabolic alkalosis, anion gap is not looked into.

A situation like this is seen with liver disease and diuretics administration.

questions.text: Which of the following is called as Australia antigen?
questions.solution:
HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is also known as the Australia antigen. It is called so because it was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person.

Sera from hepatitis B patients when observed under an electron microscope show three types of particles:

  • A spherical particle: 22nm, most abundant, contains only HBsAg.
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22nm, contains only HBsAg.
  • A double-walled spherical structure: 42nm diameter, is the complete Hepatitis B virus. It was described by Dane and is called Dane particle.

questions.text:
What is the defective DNA repair mechanism in a patient with SCID?

(SCID - severe combined immunodeficiency)
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). 

NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, enhancing T and B cell diversity. Thus, NHEJ deficiency leads to combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. 

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterised by defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R. Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria. 

X-linked SCID is the most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys. The genetic defect is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. In these patients, the thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells, resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive SCID is commonly caused by a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme. In these patients, the thymus contains remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles.

questions.text: Acrodynia is seen in poisoning with which of the following metals?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia, or pink disease, is seen in chronic mercury poisoning.

Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating and skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

Features of chronic mercury poisoning include:

  • Hydrargyrism - These patients have Danbury tremors, which are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/ Glass blower's shakes
  • Acrodynia (pink disease)
  • Minimata disease - caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury
  • Erethism - these are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity seen in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterised by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia
  • Mercuria lentis - peculiar eye changes due to exposure to mercury vapor.

questions.text: After the administration of a drug for an acute attack of migraine, a patient developed nausea and vomiting. She also developed tingling and numbness at the tips of her fingers that eventually turned blue. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated?
questions.solution:
Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of dihydroergotamine.

The numbness progressing to bluish discolouration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can eventually lead to gangrene if left untreated. This is a rare adverse effect of dihydroergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine: 

  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.solution:
The Brown–Sequard syndrome presents with contralateral loss of pain sensation.

Lateral hemisection of the spinal cord produces the Brown–Séquard syndrome (also known as the hemicord syndrome). Knife or bullet injuries and demyelination are the most common causes of this condition.

Clinical features include:

  • Ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract involvement) 
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column involvement)
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract involvement) one or two levels below the lesion
  • Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of a deep tendon reflex

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance?
questions.solution:
Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a hypopigmented, finely scaly patch on her face. There is a history of atopy in the family.  What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario of a hypopigmented, scaly patch is suggestive of pityriasis alba.

It is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature. It is seen in the age group of 3-16 years. 

Lesions have scaling and are usually not well marginated. In children, the lesions are often confined to the face and are most common on the cheeks and around the mouth and chin.

It is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.

 

Option A: In leprosy, the hypopigmented patch is often associated with atrophy, loss of sensation, and loss of sweating. The lesion is not scaly.

Option B: In pityriasis versicolor the hypopigmented macules are perifollicular in distribution. Fine, powdery branny scaling is present. Scratch sign positive. No relation to atopy.

Option D: Atopic eczema is characterized by itchy papules, hypopigmentation is not a feature.

questions.text: Gall stone chemistry most commonly seen amongst the following is:
questions.solution:
The most common gallstone chemistry seen is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

Types of gallstones:

  1. Cholesterol stones (75% of gallstones) have >70% cholesterol by weight and are composed of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. The majority of cholesterol stones have a mixed composition with bile pigments and calcium, in addition to the cholesterol. They are the most common type of gall stones worldwide and in India.
  2. Pigment stones have <20% cholesterol and are dark due to the presence of calcium bilirubinate as the major constituent.
    1. Black pigment stones (20% of gallstones) - are formed due to supersaturation of unconjugated bilirubin (seen in hereditary hemolytic anemia (like sickle cell and hereditary spherocytosis)
    2. Brown pigment stones (5% of gallstones) - formed secondary to infections (like E. coli, and Ascaris lumbricoides)

Note: Pure cholesterol stones are uncommon and account for <10% of all stones.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food.

Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

Note: In achalasia cardia, there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of the esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: What is true regarding the mirrors used at two ends of the instrument given in the image?

choices.text: Plane at one and concave at other end
Plane at one and convex at other end
Convex at one end and concave at other

questions.solution:
The image is of the Priestley-Smith retinoscope. It is a mirror retinoscope and has a plane mirror at one end and concave at other.

It has a central hole of about 2.5mm anteriorly and 4mm posteriorly.

Retinoscopy is also called a skiascopy/ shadow test. It is used to estimate refraction objectively. The instruments used are:

  • Priestley-Smith retinoscope
  • Streak retinoscope: It is self-illuminated and projects a streak rather than a circle of light.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills?

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.solution:
Minipills or progesterone-only pills (POP) do not kill sperm in the cervical canal. Progesterone-only pills act by thickening the cervical mucus (the main mechanism of all POPs except cerazette) that inhibits penetration of sperms, inhibiting tubal motility, and suppressing ovulation. 

Other advantages of POPs include a reduction in the incidence of pelvic inflammatory diseases and sexually transmitted diseases (due to thickened cervical mucus).

Due to the inhibition of tubal motility, the absolute risk of all pregnancies including ectopic pregnancy decreases, while the relative risk of ectopic pregnancy increases. But a previous history of ectopic pregnancy is not a contraindication for POP.

POPs do not affect clotting, lipid metabolism, and carbohydrate metabolism. So they can safely be used by women who are obese, breastfeeding, hypertensive, have SLE or a history of thromboembolism, diabetic with vascular disease. Significant adverse effects of POPs are irregular bleeding (mostly scanty), and secondary amenorrhea after longtime usage as it causes endometrial atrophy.

Contraindications for POPs include undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, pregnancy, known or suspected breast cancer, and benign or malignant liver tumors.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue. She is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus on treatment. On examination, there is pallor and knuckle pigmentation. Which of the following drugs could have caused her condition?
questions.solution:
Metformin can cause vitamin B12 deficiency which manifests as megaloblastic anemia (pallor, fatigue) with knuckle pigmentation.

The most common side effect of metformin is GI intolerance as nausea, bloating, abdominal cramps and diarrhoea.

Note: The exact reason why metformin causes vitamin B12 deficiency is not known. 

The proposed mechanisms include:

  • Alterations in small bowel motility, which stimulates bacterial overgrowth and consequential vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Competitive inhibition or inactivation of vitamin B12 absorption
  • Alterations in intrinsic factor (IF) levels and interaction with the cubilin endocytic receptor.
  • Inhibition of the calcium-dependent absorption of the vitamin B12-IF complex at the terminal ileum.

questions.text: You are performing a routine pap smear on a 30-year-old woman in the gynecology OPD. What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test for carcinoma cervix and is an example of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment are the components of secondary prevention. Some of the examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case.

These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures from a state of health.

questions.text: In the formula for urea clearance, C = U × V/P,  U denotes

choices.text: Concentration of urea in gm/24 hour
Concentration of urea in urine in mg/ml
Concentration of urea in blood in mg/ml

questions.solution:
In the formula for urea clearance, C=U × V/P , U denotes concentration of urea in urine mg/ml.

Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time.

  • It is calculated by the formula:

C = Clearance (mL/min)

[U]x = Urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL)

V= Urine flow rate per minute (mL/min)

[P]x = Plasma concentration of substance x (mg/mL)

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the legal term corpus delicti?
questions.solution:
Corpus delicti, also known as the body of offense, says that a crime must be proved to have occurred before a person can be convicted of committing that crime.

The main part of corpus delicti is the establishment of the identity of the dead body and infliction of violence in a particular way, at a particular time and place, by the person or persons charged with a crime and none other. 

A conviction for an offense does not necessarily depend upon the corpus delicti if there are eyewitnesses or strong corroborative evidence.

In a charge of homicide, it includes:

  • Positive identification of the dead body (victim)
  • Proof of its death by a criminal act of the accused

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Among the choices provided, Alzheimer’s disease is most commonly associated with Down’s syndrome.

Conditions most commonly associated with Down’s syndrome:

  • Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%)
  • Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alzheimer’s disease (in the 30's and 40’s)
  • Epilepsy (in about 10%)
  • Ocular disorders
  • Reduced fertility
  • Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)

questions.text: Apple peel deformity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Apple peel deformity,also known as Christmas tree Deformity is seen in type IIIb jejunoileal atresia where there is a large mesenteric gap between atretic segments and the distal loop gets retrograde blood supply from the ileocolic or right colic artery.

Types of jejunoileal atresia:

  • Type I - A mucosal web or diaphragm.
  • Type II - An atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery.
  • Type IIIa - Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap.
  • Type IIIb - An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap, in which the distal bowel receives a retrograde blood supply from the ileocolic or right colic artery.

 This tenuous blood supply has implications for anastomotic failures and a potential for ischemic necrosis of volvulus. Hence, many of these infants with this type of atresia are born with reduced intestinal length.

  • Type IV - Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: The MRI of a 50-year-old male suffering from dementia and visual hallucinations showed cortical ribboning and basal ganglia hyperintensity (FLAIR). He is most likely suffering from
questions.solution:
MRI in Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease shows

  • Cortical ribboning
  • Basal ganglia or thalamus hyperintensity on diffusion/FLAIR MRI

MRI: Cortical ribboning in CJD

questions.text: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of imipenem.

Imipenem is rapidly hydrolyzed by the enzyme renal dehydropeptidase. It is administered with cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase to inhibit the breakdown and prolong the action of imipenem.

Meropenem is not hydrolyzed by renal dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin administration is not necessary with meropenem.

The FDA approved Recarbrio (a combination of imipenem-cilastatin and relebactam) to treat hospital-acquired bacterial pneumonia and ventilator-associated bacterial pneumonia in patients ≥18 years. It was previously approved to treat patients with complicated urinary tract infections and complicated intra-abdominal infections who have limited or no alternative treatment options.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Mallampati classification except _______

choices.text: It is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation
Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures
Only hard palate is visualised in Class III
Tonsillar pillars are visualised in Class I

questions.solution:
• Only the hard palate is visualized in Class IV of Mallampati classification.

Mallampati classification is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation based on the size of the base of the tongue.

  • The patient is seated upright with the head neutral, and mouth open, the tongue protruded, and no phonation (Patient should NOT say 'aah').
  • A Mallampati classification of I to IV is assigned, based on the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate.
  • Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures attributable to a large tongue relative to the size of the oropharyngeal space, and, subsequently, leading to more difficult intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: Identify the causative organism of the following lesion
questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the picture is Herpes labialis caused by HSV The typical herpes lesions are thin walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down with superficial ulcers. They generally heal without scarring.

Clinical features of HSV

  • Cutaneous lesions
  • Mucosal MC site: buccal mucosa
  • Ophthalmic: MC cause of corneal blindness in some developed countries. Follicular conjuctivitis, acute kerato conjunctivitis also occur Chorioretinits and acute necrotising retinitis are uncommon.
  • Nervous System: HSV enchephalitis
  • Visceral: HSV esophagitis, hepatitis, tracheobronchitis etc
  • Genital herpes

Eczema herpeticum is a generalised eruption caused by herpes infections in children suffering from eczema

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of
questions.solution:
Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by cGMP.   

NO is a hormone derived from the amino acid arginine. It activates guanylyl cyclases in vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger). cGMP activates cGMP dependent protein kinase, which causes blood vessels to relax. 

cGMP is the second messenger for nitric oxide and atrial natriuretic factor.

cGMP is a valuable drug target for the treatment of various pulmonary and cardiovascular diseases. Sildenafil decreases the degradation of cGMP & Riociguat stimulates soluble guanylyl cyclase resulting in increased cGMP activity. Both drugs are used in pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: Given below is the CT abdomen of a patient who presented with diarrhea. He is most likely to be suffering from _____.
questions.solution:
The CT image depicts the accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

Clostridium difficle infection (CDI) commonly caused by the disruption of the commensal colonic microflora, due to prolonged antimicrobial use, especially antibiotics like cephalosporins, ampicillin, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones. The more severe form of CDI is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC).

Toxigenic Clostridium difficile produces toxin A (an enterotoxin) and toxin B (a cytotoxin), damaging the epithelial-cell barrier function and causing diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation, which initially appear as small whitish-yellow plaques and later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. The patient also presents with fever, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis.

On CT imaging, accordion sign, also referred to as concertina sign, may be seen.  The terms accordion or concertina refer to a harmonica like a musical instrument. The thickened edematous bowel resembles the folds of an accordion. The hyperemic-enhancing mucosa stretched over the thickened submucosal folds produces this appearance. This is also seen when the contrast gets trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes of the colon. 

Accordion sign is typical for pseudomembranous colitis but can be also seen in ischemic colitis, AIDS-related colitis, and severe edema from cirrhosis.

The CT image below depicts accordion sign:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with _____.
questions.solution:
Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with type I tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is the most common type of tyrosinemia. 

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia): Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase deficiency
  • Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome): Tyrosine transaminase deficiency
  • Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia)

questions.text: Demographic gap starts contracting in the _________ phase.
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts contracting in the late expanding phase (stage 3).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about reverse triage?

choices.text: Classifying the victims based on the severity of their injuries and their survival with treatment
Highest preference is given to severely injured patients
More injured victims are given the lowest preference
Color coding is done with red as the highest priority.

questions.solution:
Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more.

This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment. It is also done when there is a scarcity of medical resources after a disaster.

The surge capacity of hospitals is increased to accommodate for the natural disaster, by discharging non-emergent existing patients. This enables hospitals to allow for an acute increase in incoming patients.

questions.text: The emergency contraceptive of choice is _____________
questions.solution:
Emergency contraceptive of choice is levenorgestrel (progestogen-only pill).

With progestin-only regimens, levonorgestrel is taken as a single, one-time 1.5-mg dose. This is now recommended instead of two 0.75-mg doses separated by 12 or 24 hours. Dosing begins ideally within 72 hours of unprotected coitus but may be given up to 120 hours. This is found to be more effective with fewer side-effects compared to Yuzpe method (Ethinyl estradiol and Levonorgestrel).

Yuzpe method (Ethinyl estradiol and Levonorgestrel): Ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel pill each containing 50µg ethinyl estradiol and 0.5 mg of norgestrel, 2 tablets being given twice, 12 hours apart, within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. This is commonly known as Yuzpe Method. It is not preferred because of the reports of higher efficacy and fewer side effects with levonorgestrel.

RU 486 (Mifepristone): They are anti-implantation agents when given post-coitally. They act as menses inducers if given in luteal phase and can act as abortifacients when given in early pregnancy. Current accepted dose for emergency contraception is 10mg. In a comparative trial of RU486 with Yuzpe regimen, side-effects were less common with mifepristone but menstrual disturbances occurred more often.

Intra uterine contraceptive devices: Insertion of copper-T and copper-7 within 7 days of unprotected intercourse is a highly successful method for post-coital contraception. Copper-T is effective following even multiple coital exposures during a short interval especially when the delay is beyond 120 hours, but less than 1 week, making hormonal methods ineffective. IUD is particularly suitable for women who would like to continue using it as a regular contraceptive.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The frontal branch is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve.

The five terminal branches of the facial nerve are:

  • Temporal
  • Zygomatic
  • Buccal
  • Mandibular
  • Cervical

The extratemporal course of the facial nerve starts at the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone and runs anteriorly to enter the substance of the parotid gland.

Here it divides into 2 main terminal trunks, the temporofacial and the cervicofacial. These further divide and re-anastomose to give the five terminal branches.

questions.text: Which of the following osteotomies is indicated in severe osteoarthritis of the hip with large osteophytes?
questions.solution:
• Displacement osteotomy or McMurray's osteotomy is indicated in severe osteoarthritis of the hip with large osteophytes.
  • Pauwell’s varus osteotomy is indicated if the OA is due to coxa valga.
  • Valgus osteotomy is done in adduction deformity of hip. 

Osteotomy helps by changing the line of weight bearing and bringing the normal surface into the line of weight transmission.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe aching pain and weakness in his left arm and shoulder. He mentions he had recently been administered a vaccine in his left arm, but he does not remember the name of the vaccine. Which of the following could be the most common cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of brachial neuritis which is a known complication of the tetanus vaccine. 

Brachial neuritis is a dysfunction of nerves supplying the arm and shoulder without the involvement of the rest of the nervous system. It presents with a deep, steady, severe aching pain in the shoulder and arm followed by weakness and wasting in arm and shoulder muscles. Sensory loss may also be present. It is treated symptomatically by analgesics.

choices.text: A: Radial nerve, B: Posterior circumflex humeral artery
A: Radial nerve, B: Profunda Brachii artery
A: Axillary nerve, B: Posterior circumflex humeral artery
