Clinical Considerations

Anterior–inferior dislocation of the humerus (shoulder dislocation) may damage the axillary nerve or axillary artery.

Quadrilateral space syndrome(QSS): QSS is an uncommon condition that involves the compression of the posterior humeral circumflex artery and the axillary nerve within the quadrilateral space, secondary to acute trauma or from overuse, especially with overhead sports like throwing.

questions.text: In the liver, glycogen phosphorylase is inhibited by
questions.solution:
Increased levels of glucose 6 phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase in the liver.

Glycogen phosphorylase regulation:

  • Regulation of Glycogen phosphorylase is different in liver & muscle
    • In the liver, the role of glycogen is to provide free glucose for export to maintain the blood concentration of glucose
    • In muscle, the role of glycogen is to provide a source of glucose-6-phosphate for glycolysis in response to the need for ATP for muscle contraction
  • Hence increased glucose 6 phosphate acts as an allosteric inhibitor of glycogen phosphorylase
  • In both tissues, the enzyme is
    • activated by phosphorylation catalyzed by phosphorylase kinase (to yield phosphorylase a)
    • inactivated by dephosphorylation catalyzed by phosphoprotein phosphatase (to yield phosphorylase b)
  • There is instantaneous overriding of this hormonal control. Active phosphorylase a in both tissues is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate
  • In the liver, free glucose is also an inhibitor, but it is not the case in muscle
  • Muscle phosphorylase differs from the liver isoenzyme in having a binding site for 5′ AMP, which acts as an allosteric activator of the (inactive) dephosphorylated b-form of the enzyme.
  • 5′ AMP acts as a potent signal of the energy state of the muscle cell; it is formed as the concentration of ADP begins to increase.
  • cAMP activates glycogen phosphorylase. At the same time, glycogenolysis in liver can be cAMP-Independent which is mediated by Ca2+/calmodulin-sensitive phosphorylase kinase.

So Glucose 6 phosphate , ATP and glucose are inhibitors of liver glycogen phosphorylase.

AMP, Phosphorylase kinase and calcium are activators of glycogen phosphorylase.

questions.text: What is the most common type of scoliosis?
questions.solution:
Idiopathic scoliosis is the most common type of scoliosis. 

Scoliosis may be classified as:

  • Idiopathic scoliosis - No obvious cause is detected. Several genetic associations have been noted
  • Congenital scoliosis - Caused due to failure in vertebra formation or segmentation during development
  • Neuromuscular scoliosis - Caused due to neuromuscular disorders like cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, etc.
  • Scoliosis due to generalized diseases - Seen in conditions such as:
    • Neurofibromatosis
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Bone dysplasia
    • Tumors
    • Due to irradiation

questions.text: A sanitation worker presents with high-grade fever and red eyes. On examination, there is icterus, neck rigidity, the sign demonstrated below. Investigations show azotemia and elevated liver enzymes. What is the most appropriate drug to be prescribed in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of patient with fever, conjunctival suffusion (red-eye), jaundice, along with image showing kernig's sign positive and other meningeal signs i.e. neck rigidity is suggestive of a diagnosis of leptospirosis. This along with azotemia and elevated liver enzymes are features of severe leptospirosis- Weil's disease. Intravenous penicillin is most appropriate drug in severe leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Severe cases of leptospirosis, which can progress rapidly and have a high fatality rate, are associated with Weil's syndrome, characterized by triad of:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Jaundice
  • Acute kidney injury

Jaundice, when present, can be profound, and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation or relative bradycardia may also be observed. The bacteria is spread by the urine of infected animals and humans, thus making sanitary workers a high-risk population due to poor working conditions.  

The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis:

Leptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They are thin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is by microscopic agglutination test. 

Treatment for leptospirosis is based on the severity of the disease. In mild cases, oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin is preferred and in severe cases, intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone is commonly used.

questions.text: A 60 year old male is on verapamil for angina. Which of the following is not an adverse effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Tachycardia is not an adverse effect of verapamil.

Verapamil has a direct negative chronotropic effect on the heart. It is more likely to cause bradycardia because of its significant cardio depressant action. Any reflex stimulation of heart due to peripheral vasodilation is effectively countered by the direct effect.

Common side effects of verapamil include headache, gingival hyperplasia, and constipation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is associated with AV block. In hypothyroidism, there is reduced myocardial contractility and reduced pulse rate leading to a reduced stroke volume and bradycardia, AV block.

Causes of AV block:

Autonomic:

  • Carotid sinus hypersensitivity

Metabolic:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypermagnesemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency

Drug related:

  • Beta blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Adenosine
  • Digitalis
  • Lithium
  • Class 1 and class 3 anti arrhythmics

Infections:

  • Endocarditis
  • Lyme disease
  • Chaga's disease
  • Syphilis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Diphtheria
  • Toxoplasmosis

Inflammatory:

  • SLE
  • RA
  • Scleroderma

Infiltrative:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemachromatosis

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup.  On examination, size of the uterus corresponds to 26 weeks of gestation and the fetal heart rate is 130 beats/min. On ultrasound, AFI is 4. Which fetal anomaly would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of oligohydramnios. It is associated with renal agenesis. 

Oligohydramnios has the following features:

  • Fundal height less than period of gestation
  • Fetal parts easily palpable

questions.text: The given image is a histological section of which of the following organ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a histological section of the epithelium of the urinary bladder also known as transitional epithelium (urothelium).

Urothelium has 4 -6 layers of thickness of cells extending from the collecting duct of the kidney to the ejaculatory duct in males and to the urogenital membrane in females. It is named transitional epithelium as it apparently changed from a stratified cuboidal epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium. It has 3 distinctive layers as follows:

  • Basal layer made of cuboidal cells which can regenerate.
  • Intermediate layer made of polygonal cells responsible for the stretch of the organ by flattening of cells.
  • Superficial layer made of umbrella-shaped multinucleated cells which are protective and impermeable.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Onion skin fibrosis is seen in
questions.solution:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is associated with onion skin fibrosis around atrophic bile duct lumen.

  • PSC is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments.
  • Characteristic “beading” on radiographs of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree is attributable to these irregular, biliary strictures and dilations.
  • Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) targeting a nuclear envelope protein are found in approximately 65% of patients.
  • Smaller ducts, however, often have little inflammation and show a striking circumferential “onion skin” fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen, eventually leading to obliteration by a “tombstone” scar.
  • The annual risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma is 0.6 to 1.5 % with a lifetime risk of 20%.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
The partial tear of the supraspinatus tendon is responsible for painful arc syndrome rather than a complete tear.

Painful arc syndrome, also known as impingement syndrome is a condition where there is pain in the shoulder and upper arm during the mid-range of shoulder abduction (between 60-120 degrees), arising due to repetitive rubbing of the supraspinatus tendon under the coracoacromial arch.

Causes include:

  • Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon
  • Supraspinatus tendinitis
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Fracture of greater tuberosity 
  • Subacromial bursitis

Important tests for impingement are:

  • Painful arc test
  • Hawkin-Kennedy's test
  • Neer's impingement sign
  • Jobe's test

Investigations: 

  • An x-ray of the shoulder helps to detect bony avulsions, spurs, calcific deposits, sclerotic areas etc. 
  • Ultrasound of the shoulder joint is highly reliable with a sensitivity of 98%. 
  • Single contrast arthrogram is considered the gold standard in diagnosing rotator cuff tears 

Management: 

  • Conservative: heat massage, exercises, NSAIDs, subacromial steroid injections, and temporary immobilization (90% of patients recover with these measures). 
  • Indications for surgery include failure of conservative measures for 3 months, increasing loss of shoulder function, and patients who are young and active.
  • Surgical techniques include excision of adhesions and manipulation of the shoulder, excision of calcium deposits, repair of incomplete tear, acromioplasty,  acromionectomy for more disabling pain with normal range of movements, direct suture for complete rupture of the rotator cuff, rotation and transposition of the flap, and free graft.

questions.text: In which position of vocal cord, cricoarytenoid joint will be in neutral position?
questions.solution:
The cricoarytenoid joint is in neutral position when vocal cord is in intermediate or cadaveric position.

The neutral point of a joint is in the position where there is least amount of support from the ligaments and other non-muscular tissues around the joint. In this position, stress to the joint is minimized, which helps the joint to function well over time.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with astrocytoma. Which of the following drugs crosses the blood brain barrier and hence can be used for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Lomustine can cross the blood-brain barrier and is used in the management of brain tumours like astrocytoma.

Nitrosoureas like lomustine and carmustine are highly lipophilic drugs and can easily cross the blood-brain barrier. Hence, they are indicated in the management of brain tumors.

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Which of these strains of HPV is the most common cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus 6 & 11 (6 >11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts (also known as Condyloma Accuminata).

Giant Anogenital warts are known as Buschke Lowenstein Tumor. It is more common in males than in females.

Most common site:

  • In males: Frenulum, corona, glans penis
  • In females: Posterior fourchette

On histology, koilocytes are seen as shown below.

These are squamous epithelial cells that have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, hyperchromasia, and perinuclear halo.

Most of these warts resolve spontaneously. Persistent warts might transform into malignancy most commonly when infected with HPV 16 and 18.

Treatment:

Provider administered:

  1. Podophyllin (25%) - Antimitotic drug
  2. Trichloroacetic acid
  3. Cryotherapy

Both trichloroacetic acid and cryotherapy are safe in pregnancy.

Patient administered:

  1. Purified podophyllin called podophyllotoxin
  2. Imiquimod - Immunomodulator which acts on toll-like receptors 7 and 8

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is consistent with a diagnosis of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
LDH 1>LDH 2 is known as the flipped LDH pattern. It is suggestive of myocardial infarction.

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

LDH-2 HHHM Heart and RBC

LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text: The lower part of the vagina is derived from
questions.solution:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from urogenital sinus.

The upper part is derived from paramesonephric duct or Mullerian duct.

Uterus develops from two paramesonephric duct on either side which unites to form a single uterus.

questions.text: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is ________
questions.solution:
The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy. 

Complications following cardiac transplantation:

Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage.

Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur.

Other postoperative problems include infection and malignancies, especially Epstein–Barr virus-associated B-cell lymphomas.

The image given below shows allograft arteriopathy. There is severe diffuse concentric intimal thickening producing critical stenosis. The internal elastic lamina and media are intact (Movat pentachrome stain, elastin black)

questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome or Zellweger's syndrome is characterized by the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acid, abnormalities of synthesis of bile acids and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

It occurs in individuals with a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes. It is due to mutations in genes encoding certain proteins called peroxins (involved in various steps of peroxisome biogenesis) in all tissues. They accumulate C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. It causes severe neurological symptoms and most patients die in the first year of life.

Because of the poor outcome and high disease burden associated with Zellweger's syndorme, genetic counselling should be offered to parents of affected children. Carriers can be offered prenatal or preimplantation genetic diagnosis. Treatment is often supportive and symptom-based.

This question was asked in the recent AIIMS examination, making it a potential repeat.

The retinal pigment epithelium consists of a single layer of hexagonal cells lying between the layer of rods and cones (photoreceptor) and Bruch’s membrane.

Pigment epithelium:

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism is not seen in MEN 2B.

MEN syndrome:

  • MEN-1 syndrome is caused by germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called Menin.
  • MEN-2 syndrome comprises two distinct groups of disorders that are caused by gain-of-function mutations of the RET proto-oncogene at chromosomal locus 10q11.2.

MEN 2B is also called MEN 3 and is characterized by:

  • Medullary thyroid cancer
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
  • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Three days after being initiated on a certain enzyme inhibiting drug, a patient developed sharply demarcated skin lesions with necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs was likely started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient developing skin necrosis a few days after starting a new drug is likely to be suffering from warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Warfarin is an anti-coagulant which acts by competitive inhibition of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby preventing the activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S. Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation). Skin necrosis is a rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy.

Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk for developing warfarin-induced skin necrosis. This is because these proteins, which are anti-thrombotic, have a shorter half-life as compared to the clotting factors inhibited by warfarin. Initiation of warfarin caused a sudden drop in the levels of protein C and S before they inhibit the clotting factors, due to which there is hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. The toes, thighs, buttocks and breasts are commonly involved.

This adverse effect can be prevented by co-administration of warfarin with a parenteral anticoagulant such as heparin in the initial few days, until the therapeutic INR range is achieved, before continuing with warfarin alone.

Treatment of this condition is by immediately discontinuing warfarin. Vitamin K can be administered for reversal of the drug effect. Patients are started on an alternative anticoagulant such as heparin or LMWH.

Other Options:

Option B: Aspirin acts by irreversibly inhibiting the enzymes cyclo-oxygenase and thromboxane. It is an antiplatelet drug and the most important side effects include bleeding tendencies. 

Option C: Atorvastatin is a statin drug which inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase. Important side effects inclue myositis and hepatotoxicity.

Option D: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone which inhibits the enzyme DNA gyrase. Important side effects include cartilage damage in children and Achilles tendon rupture in adults.

Related Pearl: Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: Which of the following index and its component is correctly matched?

choices.text: Physical quality of life index: Literacy rate
Human development index: Life expectancy at age 1
Physical quality of life index: Life expectancy at birth

questions.solution:
The literacy rate is a component of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI).

The three components of PQLI are:

  1. Infant mortality rate
  2. Literacy rate
  3. Life expectancy at age 1

In the PQLI, each component is given a score of 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best. The average of all three is taken, and then the PQLI is scored between 0 and 100. In India, PQLI is 65.

Literacy rate

questions.solution:

In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark whereas in T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white.

STIR (Short tau inversion recovery) is done to detect bone marrow oedema.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient with a past history of cryptorchidism presented with a scrotal mass.  Scrotal skin was normal.  Ultrasonography confirmed testicular carcinoma. Which of the following group of lymph nodes are unlikely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The inguinal group of lymph nodes are only affected in testicular carcinoma if the scrotal skin is involved.

The following groups of lymph nodes are involved in the lymphatic drainage of testes:

  • Right testis- inter-aortocaval nodes ---> pre-aortic and para-aortic nodes 
  • Left testis- pre-aortic and para-aortic noes ---> inter-aortocaval nodes
  • Scrotal skin- inguinal nodes ---> external iliac nodes ---> common iliac nodes
  • Retroperitoneal lymph nodes

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumour and it commonly occurs in patients with a history of cryptorchidism. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP). 

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH?
questions.solution:
Placenta previa does not cause secondary postpartum hemorrhage. It causes primary postpartum hemorrhage.

Primary/early: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth.

Secondary/ late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is ____.
questions.solution:
The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg.

Prostaglandins are paracrine/autocrine hormones and act locally at the site of production. Main sources for:

  1. PGF2α  - Decidua and promotes myometrial contractility
  2. PGE2 - fetal membranes (amnion) and induces labor and promotes cervical effacement and dilatation
  3. PGI2 - Myometrium 

Carboprost tromethamine (hemabate) is the 15-methyl derivative of prostaglandin F2 alpha. It is approved for the treatment of uterine atony at a dose of 0.25 mg IM. This dose can be repeated if necessary at 15- to 90-minute intervals up to a maximum of eight doses (2 mg).

It is the best drug to control PPH. ls also used an abortifacient in the second trimester.

Contraindications include asthmatic women and those with suspected amniotic fluid embolism, as they cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) Neurological Impairment Scale?

choices.text: It is based on the Frankel classification of spinal cord injury
Motor function is assessed using Medical Research Council grading system of 0-4
Normal functional motor power is grade 2/4 or higher
According to scale D, sensation is present, motor is absent

questions.solution:
The American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) neurological evaluation system is an internationally accepted method of neurological evaluation and is based on the Frankel classification of spinal cord injury.

Option b

Motor function is assessed using the Medical Research Council (MRC) grading system (0–5).

Option c

Normal functional motor power is grade 3/5 or higher.

Option d

According to the impairment scale D, the sensation is present and the motor is useful (MRC grade more than or equal to 3/5).

According to the medical research council grading of muscle power, grade 4 is an active movement against resistance but power is less than full. And grade 5 corresponds to normal power.

Related Pearl: Neurological Impairment Examination

The Medical Research Council (MRC) grading of muscle power

Grading Description
0 No movement
1 Flicker of movements
2 Active movement with gravity elimination
3 Active movement against gravity
4 Active movement against resistance but power less than full
5 Normal power

The ASIA (American Spinal Injury Association) neurological impairment scale:

Impairment scale Description
A Complete impairment
B Sensation present, motor absent
C Sensation present, motor present, but not useful (MRC grade less than 3/5)
D Sensation present, motor useful (MRC grade more than equal to 3/5)
E Normal functions

questions.text:
On chest x-ray PA view, right cardiac border is formed by _______.

1. Superior vena cava
2. Inferior vena cava
3. Right atrium
4. Right ventricle
questions.solution:
On a chest x-ray PA view,

Right cardiac border formed by

  • Superior vena cava (SVC)
  • Right atrium
  • Inferior vena cava (IVC)

Left cardiac border formed by

  • Subclavian artery
  • Aortic knuckle
  • Pulmonary artery segment
  • Left atrial appendage
  • Left ventricle

Posteroanterior view (PA view) is the most commonly done chest x-ray view.

PA view is usually done in full inspiration and standing position.

Ideally, there should be no rotation. If there is no rotation, the distance between the medial end of the clavicle and the spinous process will be equidistant, on both sides. 

In a normal chest x-ray, the left dome of the diaphragm is lower than the right because the heart pushes the left dome down.

questions.text: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes all except _____.
questions.solution:
The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism does not include metabolic acidosis.

Classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism:

  • Hypotension
  • Hypoxia
  • DIC

Conditions predisposing to the development of amniotic fluid embolism:

  1. Rapid labour
  2. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
  3. Tears in uterine and other large pelvic veins
  4. Older maternal age
  5. Post-term pregnancy
  6. Labour induction or augmentation
  7. Eclampsia
  8. Cesarean/forceps/vacuum delivery
  9. Placental abruption/placenta previa
  10. Polyhydramnios.

questions.text: The earliest detectable congenital malformations by USG is ______
questions.solution: Anencephaly, holoprosencephaly, and ventral wall defects have very high rate of detection in first trimester. The remaining of the anomalies can be detected in second trimester.

questions.text: A 15-year old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. An X-ray of his left hip joint is shown below. What is the sign seen?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). The radiograph shows the Trethowan's sign. 

The Klein line is a line drawn along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Option B: Catterall's sign is seen in Perthes disease.

Option C: Alli's sign is seen in DDH.

Option D: Dagger sign is seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state is erythromycin.

Erythromycin for 7 days is very effective for eradicating the diphtheria carrier state or acute infections.

Schistosoma japonicum
Paragonimus westermani

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is ___________.
questions.solution:
TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV(who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).

Interferon-gamma release assays include:

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
  • T-SPOT.TB

QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IFN-γ produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.

 T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-γ.

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample. (Option A and B)

questions.text: A pathologist noted the following microscopic finding while examining a slide of a kidney. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, filled with casts, resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.

Option A: In acute tubular necrosis, there is focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis.

Option C: In acute interstitial nephritis, there is patchy edema and mononuclear cell infiltrates.

Option D: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), wire-loop lesions are seen.

choices.text: Axial ratio is less than or equal to 3

Elastin is a fibrous protein.

questions.text: In which condition is excessive urinary excretion of  5- hydroxy indole acetic acid seen?
questions.solution:
Excessive urinary excretion of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) is seen in carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is marked by symptoms of bronchospasm, cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. It occurs due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism by tumors commonly in the small intestine, liver and lungs. It is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA.

questions.text: The most common site of iris coloboma is
questions.solution:
Iris coloboma is seen most commonly in the inferonasal quadrant.

Congenital coloboma (absence of tissue) of iris, ciliary body and choroid may be seen in association or independently. It can be typical or atypical.

Typical coloboma is seen in the inferonasal quadrant and occurs due to defective closure of the embryonic fissure. It can be complete or incomplete

  • Complete coloboma extends from pupil to the optic nerve, with a sector-shaped gap occupying about one-eighth of the circumference of the retina, choroid, ciliary body, iris .
  • Incomplete coloboma may involve the iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary body and part of choroid (i.e. stops short of optic nerve). 

Atypical coloboma is occasionally found in other positions. It is usually incomplete.

questions.text: In Menke’s disease, which of the following enzymes would be affected?
questions.solution:
Menke’s disease is due to defective lysyl oxidase.

It is an X‐linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A, which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase‐α polypeptide.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text:
Choose the option with correct matches:
Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule a. Surgical Intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 b. Planting a bullet inside a stab wound
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon c. Relationship between trauma and new growth
4. Ewing's Postulates d. Chronological sequence of bullets fired
questions.solution:
The correct match would be as follows:

Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule d.Chronological sequence of bullets fired

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 a. Surgical Intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon b.Planting a bullet inside a stab wound 
4. Ewing's Postulates c. Relationship between trauma and new growth

 

Puppe's rule: Helps in determining the sequence of bullets to hit the skull, when there are multiple bullet injuries to skull. The fracture line resulting from the later bullet will typically stop at the previously formed one.

Kennedy's phenomenon: Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact as the evaluation of wound as entry or exit wound becomes difficult.

Rayalaseema phenomenon: Here a person is killed by stab injury, and a bullet is implanted inside to mislead the investigation.

Ewing's postulates: Establishes a relationship between trauma and new growth.

The following postulates should be satisfied before a relationship between trauma and new growth is accepted:

  • Evidence of previous integrity of the injured part.
  • Undeniable and adequate trauma must be proved.
  • There must be a proof of reasonable time interval between injury and appearance of tumour.
  • Disease must develop at the exact site of injury.
  • The nature of the tumour must be proved.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?

choices.text: The extent does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.solution:
Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factor leading to increased proliferation of fibrous tissue.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound (option A) and rarely regresses on its own.  It is more common in darker-pigmented ethnicities.

It can arise from surgery, burns, skin inflammation, infections, ear piercing, and even spontaneously. It occurs 3 months to years after the initial insult with even minor injuries causing keloid formation.

It most commonly occurs on the skin of the earlobe, deltoid, presternal, upper back, and rarely extends into the subcutaneous tissue.

The histology of keloid scars shows excess collagen and hypervascularity with collagen fibres arranged haphazardly in loose sheets (option C).

Treatment: Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision alone has a high rate of recurrence (option B). The following can be done:

  • Pressure - local moulds or elastic garments.
  • Silicone gel sheeting.
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection.
  • Excision and steroid injections.
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy).
  • Intralesional excision.
  • Laser to reduce redness.
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage.

Differences between Keloids and Hypertrophic scars:

  Keloid  Hypertrophic scar 
Incidence  Rare  Frequent 
Ethnic groups  African, American, Asian, Hispanic  No predilection 
Prior injury  Yes  Yes 
Site predilection Neck, chest, earlobes, shoulders, upper back  Anywhere 
Genetics  Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration  No 
Timing  Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury  4-6 weeks post-injury 
Symptoms  Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins Raised, some pruritus, respects wound confines 
Regression and contracture  No, and rare  Frequent 
Histology  Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibres in random orientation  Parallel orientation of collagen fibres

questions.text: Neil Mooser reaction is positive in _______.
questions.solution:
Neil Mooser's reaction is positive in case of Rickettsia typhi.

Neil Mooser reaction:

Seen in endemic typhus which is caused by R. typhi.

When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with blood from a case of endemic typhus, they develop a fever and a characteristic scrotal inflammation.

The scrotum becomes enlarged and the testes cannot be pushed into the abdomen.

It is also known as the tunica reaction. It is negative with R.prowazekii

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to you with fatigue & palpitations. She gives a history of 4 spontaneous abortions early during pregnancy & provides a lab report showing very high titers of anti- beta2 glycoprotein 1. On cardiac auscultation, you hear a pansystolic murmur.  Which of the following vegetations would you most likely find on Echocardiography?
questions.solution:
The vegetations depicted in "Image D", consistent with Libman Sacks Endocarditis are most likely to be seen in Echo.

The h/o repeated, early spontaneous abortions & lab report showing high titers of anti beta2 glycoprotein1 are strongly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS). With this background, the given presentation of fatigue, palpitations, and finding of the pan-systolic murmur (most likely of MR) should raise a strong suspicion for Libman sack’s endocarditis. It is characterized by very small vegetations, on either or both sides of the valve as given in "Image D".

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may occur alone (primary) or in association with other autoimmune diseases, mainly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (secondary).

Diagnosis:

  • The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia.
  • The presence of at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion is compatible with the diagnosis, in the absence of other thrombophilia causes.
  • Clinical criteria include:
    • Vascular thrombosis defined as one or more clinical episodes of arterial, venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ
    • Pregnancy morbidity, defined as:
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond the tenth week of gestation
      • One or more premature births of a morphologically normal neonate before the thirty-fourth week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before the tenth week of gestation

  • Laboratory criteria for APS include high titers of any 1 of the following three antiphospholipid antibodies on two occasions, 12 weeks apart 

    • Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - It is measured indirectly by
      • Diluted Russell's viper venom time assay (most specific) 
      • Kaolin coagulation time(KCT)
      • prolongation of aPTT
    • Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibody assay (most sensitive)
    • Anti-β2GPI (glycoprotein 1) antibodies assay

Related Pearl: Vegetations in Various Types of Endocarditis

questions.text: A child suffering from intermittent bronchial asthma is being treated with β2 agonists. Which of the following side effects would you not expect?
questions.solution:
β2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to β2 receptor-mediated glycogenolysis and glucagon release.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists:

  • Hypokalemia - direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions
  • Tachycardia - reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on β2 receptors and direct effect on cardiac β1 receptors (β2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) 
  • Muscle tremors - direct effect on β2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Tolerance - desensitization on long-term use

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about battered baby syndrome?

choices.text: Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body
It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly
The syndrome is a result of firearm injuries

questions.solution:
Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are a classical feature of a child with battered baby syndrome.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

The syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury varies with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of appendicular skeleton, skull and spine

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was rapidly administered a muscle relaxant, which resulted in erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso, associated with a fall in arterial pressure and an increase in heart rate were noted. Which of the following is most commonly implicated?
questions.solution:
The above clinical signs and symptoms caused by the rapid administration of muscle relaxant are attributed to histamine release. The side effect of histamine release is most often noted following the administration of the benzylisoquinoline class of muscle relaxants, mainly by d-tubocurarine.

Clinical features associated with histamine release include erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso, as well as a brief decrease in arterial pressure with a slight to moderate increase in heart rate. The serosal mast cells, located near the blood vessels and nerves in the skin and connective tissue are principally involved in the degranulation process. 

The following table shows autonomic effects of various neuromuscular blocking drugs:

Drug Type Autonomic Ganglia Cardiac Muscarinic Receptors Histamine Release
Depolarizing
Substance
Succinylcholine  Stimulates  Stimulates  Less
Benzyl-isoquinolinium Compounds
d-Tubocurarine
(dTc)		  Blocks  No effect  Moderate
Mivacurium  No effect  No effect  Less
Atracurium  No effect  No effect  Less
Cisatracurium  No effect  No effect  None
Steroidal Compounds
Vecuronium  No effect  No effect  None
Rocuronium  No effect  Weak blockage  None
Pancuronium  No effect  Moderate blockage  None


From the above table, it is evident that d-tubocurarine is the most potent histamine releaser. Also, dTc causes hypotension both by histamine release and ganglion blockade.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., aspirin), in addition to anti-histamines, help prevent the development of hypotension with the administration of d-Tubocurarine. Slower injection rates have been shown to reduce the incidence of this side effect.

questions.text: Functional residual capacity is:

choices.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.solution:
Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

From the picture given below, (FRC = ERV + RV).

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath.

Lung volumes, capacities, and their combinations are being tested year after year in the various competitive exams.

questions.text: Immunohistochemical testing was performed on a biopsy sample taken from a patient with breast cancer. Which of the following subtypes indicates the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
The luminal A molecular subtype of breast cancer is associated with the best prognosis. 

The cells in breast cancer may overexpress estrogen receptors (ER), progesterone receptors (PR), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2/neu (HER2/neu), and androgen receptors (AR). Ki-67 mitotic index indicates the degree of mitosis or proliferation. 

Based on these factors, breast cancer is classified into 5 subtypes. These include: 

  • luminal A
  • luminal B
  • HER2/neu enriched
  • basal
  • normal-like group

The luminal A subtype is the most common. They are defined as hormone receptor-positive (ER-positive and/or PR-positive), HER2/neu negative, and low Ki67 by immunohistochemistry. These tumors have a low histological grade, low degree of nuclear pleomorphism, and low mitotic activity. They are associated with a good prognosis and a significantly lower relapse rate. 

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: With respect to a disinfectant, what does the phenol coefficient indicate?
questions.solution:
Phenol coefficient indicates the efficacy of a disinfectant as compared to phenol.

Phenol coefficient = The dilution of test disinfectant which kills microorganisms in a given time ÷ The dilution of phenol which kills the microorganism in the same time under identical conditions. 

The Rideal-Walker coefficient helps in determining the phenol co-efficient (PC) which indicates the power of a disinfectant. A PC value of more than 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. It is only of historical value.

 Other methods for testing of disinfectants:

  • Chick Martin test: Tests the activity in the presence of organic matter, so it simulates natural conditions.
  • Kelsey Sykes (capacity) test: Tests the activity on repeated use of a disinfectant. 
  • Kelsey and Maurer test: Determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital practice.

Joseph Lister first introduced phenol (carbolic acid) as an antiseptic to sterilize surgical instruments and  clean wounds. Lister's work led to a reduction in postoperative infections and made surgery safer for patients, distinguishing him as the 'Father of Modern Surgery' and 'Father of Antiseptic Surgery'.

questions.text: Anxious parents brought their infant to the pediatric outpatient with complaints of an abnormal increase in the size of his head. Investigations revealed hydrocephalus due to the vein of Galen malformation. Identify the great vein of Galen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The great vein of Galen is marked as '1' in the image given above.

The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is a short median vessel, formed by the joining of the internal cerebral veins. It then curves sharply up around the splenium of the corpus callosum and opens into the anterior end of the straight sinus, located along the junction between the falx and the tentorium cerebelli.

Clinical significance:

  • Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformations (VGAM) is the most common form of symptomatic cerebrovascular malformation in neonates and infants.
  • Vein of Galen malformation can result in hydrocephalus, heart failure, or rarely, hemorrhage.
  • There may be the absence of great vein of Galen in some congenital disorders.

The other veins marked are shown in the image below:

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The appropriate management of a 45-year-old with a positive pap smear and post-coital bleeding is a colposcopy-directed biopsy.

A per speculum examination must be done whenever a female comes with post-coital bleeding in order to evaluate for carcinoma of the cervix. If growth is visible, a punch biopsy should be done, and else if no growth is visible, then a pap smear is done. A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and pap co-test every 5 years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If a pap smear is suspicious, then screening is continued till 75 years. HIV+ve women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.

Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
