questions.text: Which of the following is false about secretin?
questions.solution:
• Secretin is secreted by S cells that are located deep in the glands of the mucosa of the upper portion of the small intes­tine.
  • The secretion of secretin is increased by the products of protein digestion and by acid bathing the mucosa of the upper small intestine.
  • Functions:
    • Increases the secretion of bicarbonate by the duct cells of the pancreas and biliary tract.
    • Augments the action of CCK in producing pancreatic secretion of diges­tive enzymes.
    • Decreases gastric acid secretion and may cause contraction of the pyloric sphincter.
    • Stimulates insulin and inhibits glucagon secretion.

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
A slowly progressive swelling, with a variable consistency, lifting the ear lobe, is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily affects the parotid gland, particularly its superficial lobe. It is also referred to as a mixed tumor due to its combination of epithelial and mesenchymal components. This tumor most commonly occurs in females around the age of 40.

Clinical features:

  • Painless, slow-growing swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, variable in consistency
  • Lifts the earlobe
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone.
  • In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils, and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.
  • Features of malignancy - a sudden increase in size, ulceration of the overlying skin, facial nerve palsy (involvement of facial nerve), painful swelling, and restriction of jaw movements.

Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the investigation of choice in diagnosing pleomorphic adenoma. Open biopsy is contraindicated due to the chances of injury to the facial nerve.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy. Radical parotidectomy is performed for malignant pleomorphic adenoma.

Other options:

Option A: Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignant tumor that usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling since it most commonly affects the tibial diaphysis.

Option B:  Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  1. Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development.
  2. Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  3. Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  4. Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option D: Sebaceous cysts are retention cysts of the sebaceous glands that present as smooth, non-tender, non-transillumination swelling with a punctum (in 70% of the patients). 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

Type of Salivary gland

Location

Frequency of tumor

Percentage of malignancy

Major

Parotid

Common

10–20%
 

Submandibular

Uncommon

50%
 

Sublingual

Very rare

85%

Minor

Upper aero-digestive tract

Rare

90%

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium for the past 6 hours. His wife reports him having a fall in the bathroom 4 weeks ago. On evaluation, the following funduscopic findings are noted. What will be your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and fundus examination are most probably suggestive of chronic subdural hematoma. The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema.

Chronic SDH is a collection of blood breakdown products that are at least 2 to 3 weeks old. It occurs in patients without a clear history of head trauma, as they may arise from a minor head injury. Alcoholics, the elderly, and patients on anticoagulation are at higher risk for developing chronic SDH than others.

Patients may present with headaches, seizures, confusion, contralateral hemiparesis, or coma. 

A chronic SDH >1 cm or any symptomatic SDH should be surgically drained.

Nomenclature

Time

Acute  SDH

<3 days

Subacute SDH

4–21 days

Chronic SDH

> 21 days

 

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following feature is not common to arteritic and non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION)?
questions.solution:
Cranial nerve palsies are seen only in the case of arteritic AION.

Features common to both Arteritic AION Non-arteritic AION
Age > 40years >60years 40-60years
Vision loss is sudden, reduced color vision, altitudinal or central field defect Usually severe vision loss Usually moderate vision loss
Usually painless, usually no episodes of prior amaurosis Headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica, cranial nerve palsies. Temporal artery biopsy – giant cell granuloma. Associated with hypertension, diabetes, nocturnal hypotension.
 

ESR >40mm in the first hour

Treatment: steroids

ESR 20-40mm in the first hour.

Treatment: carbidopa-levodopa tried, not found to be effective.

questions.text: Gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is
questions.solution:
Laparoscopy is the gold standard in the diagnosis of endome­triosis.

The diagnosis should be validated by peritoneal and tissue biopsy.

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy.
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important property of synthetic mesh in reconstructive pelvic surgery?

choices.text: Ability to resist tissue in growth

questions.solution:
The pore size is the most important property of synthetic mesh. Pore size is also the basis of tissue ingrowth, angiogenesis, flexibility and strength.

Bacteria generally measure less than 1 micrometer, granulocytes and macrophages are more than 10 micrometers.

Thus, a mesh with pore size less than 10 micrometer will allow bacteria but not macrophage infiltration and thereby predispose to infection.

Type I mesh has the lowest rate of infection compared with types II, III.

Meshes are either monofilament or multifilament and monofilament mesh is the best choice for reconstructive pelvic surgery.

Synthetic mesh is classified as type I through IV, based on the pore size.

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical markers would be positive in a patient with adenocarcinoma lung?
questions.solution:
Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1), mucin, and napsin-A are positive in adenocarcinoma lung.

TTF-1 is required for normal lung development. It can be used to distinguish primary adenocarcinoma of the lungs (TTF-1 positive) from other histological types of lung cancers, metastatic adenocarcinoma, and mesothelioma (TTF-1 negative).

P40 and P63 are the markers for squamous cell carcinoma.

Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

The Lung Cancer Awareness Month, marked in countries across the world every November, in an effort to improve the outcomes for lung cancer patients across the world.

questions.text: The given image depicts which of the following flaps?
questions.solution:
The image is that of a transposition flap, which is the most basic design that leaves a graftable donor site.

Local flaps are:

  • Transposition flap: (a) Z-plasty for lengthening scars or tissues and (b) Rhomboid flap for cheek, temple, back and flat surface defects
  • Rotation flap for convex surfaces
  • Advancement flap for flexor surfaces may need triangles excised at the base (Burow's triangles)
  • V to Y advancement commonly used for fingertips and extremities
  • Bilobed flap for convex surfaces
  • Bipedicle flap for eyelids

questions.text: The following colony morphology on blood agar is indicative of
questions.solution:
The given image shows the frosted glass appearance of the colonies, which is characteristic of Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is the etiologic agent of anthrax—a common disease of livestock and, occasionally, of humans—and the only obligate pathogen within the genus Bacillus. It is a gram-positive, endospore-forming (non-bulging spores), rod-shaped bacterium. Culture characteristics are as follows:

  • On agar, irregularly round colonies are formed, 2 to 3 mm in diameter, raised, dull, opaque, greyish white, with a frosted glass appearance.
  • Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.
  • On gelatin stab, they appear as inverted fir tree appearance.
  • On solid media with penicillin, they show a string of pearls appearance in culture smear.

Bamboo stick appearance on Gram staining (image):

questions.text: Superantigen is produced by
questions.solution:
Superantigens are the third variety of biological class of antigens, recently described in last decade. The unique feature of superantigens is that they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen presenting cells (APCs).

Examples of Superantigens

Bacterial superantigens:

  • Staphylococcal toxin: TSST, Exfoliative toxin, Enterotoxins
  • Streptococcal toxin: Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE)-A and C
  • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen-l
  • Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis

Viral: EBV, CMV, Rabies nucleocapsid, HIV encoded nef (negative regulatory factor)

Fungal superantigen: Malassezia furfur

Note: The streptococcal toxins SPE-A, and SPE-C, which are superantigens are produced by streptococcal pyogenes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Central bronchiectasis is a typical feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), not distal bronchiectasis. 

ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonization of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis, and respiratory compromise. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts. The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:
Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml
Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A. fumigatus extract
Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies
Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL

Treatment - The use of systemic glucocorticoids is indicated for ABPA, but the course should be tapered by 3-6 months. Antifungal agents like itraconazole, voriconazole, and newer azoles can be used for over 4 months to control disease activity. Monoclonal antibodies against IgE, IL-4, and IL-5 receptors can be used for severe refractory cases.

questions.text: Which of the following has been most commonly implicated as a cause of dialysis-induced hypotension in patients?
questions.solution:
Acetate is used as a buffer in the dialysate solution. It is the most common cause of dialysis-induced hypotension because of its vasodilatory and cardio-depressive effects.

For this reason, acetate is less commonly used these days and has been largely replaced by bicarbonate.

questions.text: Soft contact lens is made up of
questions.solution:
Soft lenses are made up of HEMA– hydroxyethyl methacrylate.

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate)
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a woman with atrophic vaginitis with complaints of itching?
questions.solution:
Atrophic vaginitis is treated with topical estrogen vaginal cream.

Atrophic vaginitis (senile vaginitis) is seen in postmenopausal women due to the thinning of vaginal mucosa (lack of estrogen). They present as discomfort (itching) and dryness in the vulva with dyspareunia. Occasionally, they may also complain of yellowish or blood-stained vaginal discharge.

The possibility of a coexisting carcinoma of the body or the cervix has to be excluded before treating it with estrogen supplements. Though topical application is the initial treatment, systemic estrogens (hormone replacement therapy) can be considered based on the patient's profile and the severity of the symptoms.

Other options:

Option A: Steroids are not indicated in the management of atrophic vaginitis as the inflammation is due to a lack of estrogen. Furthermore, they may predispose the patient to vaginal infections.

Option C: Antihistamines antagonize histamine receptors and prevent the allergic response. Since atrophic vaginitis is not an allergy response, they are not indicated in the treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an enzyme inducer?
questions.solution:
Sodium valproate is not an enzyme inducer. It is metabolized by CYP2C9/19 and is an inhibitor of CYP2C9.

Phenytoin, phenobarbital, and carbamazepine are inducers of CYP and UGT enzymes.

questions.text: In India, dying declaration is accepted under
questions.solution:
In India, dying declaration is accepted under IEA section 32.

Other options:

  • IEA section 139: cross examination of a witness
  • IEA section 114 A: Doctrine of Adverse Inference: When a rape victim states that she did not consent, the presumption is usually in her favour.
  • IEA section 45: Expert witness

questions.text: Which of the following is false with respect to the period of communicability?

choices.text: Measles – from 4 days before to 4 days after the appearance of rash
Hepatitis B – till the disappearance of HbsAg and appearance anti-Hbs
Influenza – 5 days before the onset of symptoms
Chickenpox – 2 days before to 5 days after the appearance of rash

questions.solution:
Healthy adults may be able to transmit the infection to others from 1 day before the onset of symptoms and up to 5 to 7 days after.

Related Pearl: Period of communicability of important diseases

 

Disease Period of communicability
Chicken pox  1-2 days before to 4-5 days after appearance of rash
Hepatitis B One month before the appearance of Jaundice till the disappearance of HbsAg
Measles 4 days before to 5 days after appearance of rash
Rubella 7 days before to 7 days after the rash
Mumps 4-6 days before to 7 days after symptoms onset
Pertussis 7 days before to 3 weeks after the onset of paroxysms
Diphtheria Up to 4 weeks after disease onset
Meningococcal meningitis Till meningococci are absent from nasal/throat swabs
Influenza 1 to 2 days before and 1 to 2 days after onset of symptoms
Tetanus Not communicable

questions.text: What is the retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm known as?
questions.solution:
The retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm is known as backspatter.

Gunshot contact wounds and close-range discharges may cause blood and tissue fragments to enter the muzzle. It is due to negative pressure created following the discharge. This is known as backspatter.

Sometimes blood and tissue may soil the hand or arm of the person firing the gun, a matter of considerable significance in forensic science.

Option A: Blowback phenomenon: This is seen at the entry wound in a contact shot against a bone, where the gases rebound against the bone and exit through the entry wound, creating a stellate shaped margin at the entry wound.

Option B & C: Retrodispersion and backward scatter are not effects seen in firearm injuries.

questions.text: Fixation at phallic phase of psychosexual development can be seen in ___________
questions.solution:
Fixation at the phallic phase of psychosexual development can be seen in hysteria. The phallic/Oedipus complex is the primary cause of hysteria and other neurotic symptoms.

The psychosexual theory was proposed by Sigmund Freud.

Phase of sexual development Disorders resulting from fixation of regression to this phase
Oral phase (birth- 1.5 years)

Alcohol dependence or drug dependence

Schizophrenia

Severe mood disorders
Anal phase (1.5-3 years) OCD
Phallic/Oedipal phase (3-5 years) Oedipus complex is the primary cause of hysteria.
Latency phase (5-12 years) Neurotic disorder
Genital phase (>12 years) Neurotic disorder

questions.text: During a health checkup in a factory, a 52-year-old worker complained of progressive cough and weight loss for the past 6 months. Chest X-ray showed a mass in the right apical region of the lung with pleural effusion. The biopsy sample obtained stained positive for calretinin. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Immunohistochemical analysis will be positive for TTF-1.
Asbestos exposure is the major risk factor.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy showing positive calretinin is suggestive of mesothelioma. The immunohistochemical analysis will be negative for TTF-1 in mesothelioma. TTF-1 is positive in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Malignant mesothelioma is the most common tumor of the pleura. Exposure to asbestos is the major known risk factor. The latency period between asbestos exposure and the development of mesothelioma is at least 20 years. It is more common in males, usually seen after 40 years of age. It has a very poor prognosis.

Histological subtypes include:

  • Epithelial
  • Sarcomatous
  • Biphasic

The physical characteristics of specific fibers are important for causation. They are:

  • Serpentine fibers: Large and curly, not able to travel beyond larger airways.
  • Amphibole fibers: The narrow, straight amphibole fibers, in particular, the crocidolite fibers navigate distally into the pulmonary parenchyma and are most clearly associated with mesotheliomas.

It is not bilaterally symmetrical. Its clinical features include:

  • Dyspnoea
  • Chest pain
  • Pleural effusion – in 90% cases

Diagnostic imaging includes chest X-ray, CT scan, and FDG-PET scan to determine the extent of tumor invasion and to evaluate occult metastases. Thoracoscopy or open pleural biopsy with special staining of tumor samples is required to differentiate mesotheliomas from adenocarcinomas.

Treatment includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Extrapleural pneumonectomy and total pleurectomy are two commonly used surgical procedures.

Related Pearl: Differentiation of Mesothelioma from Adenocarcinoma

Immunohistochemical Results

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma
Calretinin, WT-1, CK 5/6, D2-40 (Podoplanin)

Positive

Negative
TTF-1

Negative

Positive

Carcinoembryonic Antigen

Negative

Positive

Vimentin

Positive

Negative

Low molecular weight cytokeratins 

Positive

Negative

Electron microscopic features

Long, sinuous villi

Short, straight villi with fuzzy glycocalyx

questions.text: The structure that lies superficial to the flexor retinaculum is _________
questions.solution:
Ulnar nerve and vessels pass superficial to flexor retinaculum.

  • The flexor retinaculum is a strong, short, and broad fibrous band, measuring 2.5–3 cm both transversely and proximodistally.
  • It is attached medially to the pisiform bone and the hook of the hamate bone. Laterally, it splits into superficial and deep laminae.

The structures lying deep to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Lateral compartment:
    • Flexor carpi radialis
  • Medial compartment:
    • Median nerve
    • Flexor pollicis longus
    • 4 tendons each of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus

Structures lying superficial to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Palmaris longus tendon
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar vessels

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent​ respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the above clinical history and examination, the most probable diagnosis is hyper IgE syndrome (Job’s syndrome).

It is an autosomal dominant primary immunodeficiency disease caused by  a mutation of STAT3 gene. Neutrophils do not generate an immune response, probably due to a defect in chemotaxis. Patients present with recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent lung infections (pneumatoceles), eczema, eosinophilia and high serum levels of lgE.

questions.text: The histopathological slide given below is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows a row of tombstones appearance, which is classically seen in pemphigus vulgaris. 

In this condition, there is a suprabasal splitting of the epidermis leading to blister formation. The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones as shown in the histology image below.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins, desmogleins 1 and 3 expressed in the skin and mucosa.

Clinically, the patients present with ill-defined, irregular, slow-to-heal oral lesions and erosions. Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may arise on normal skin or an erythematous base. The rupture of such blisters produces painful erosions and heals without scarring.

Nikolsky's sign is positive which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing erosion.

Direct immunofluorescence is considered the most accurate confirmatory test of this condition. It shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance as seen below.

questions.text: FFA picture shows the following. The most likely diagnosis based on the image is
questions.solution:
The image depicts smoke stack pattern in FFA. This is characteristically seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Fundus fluorescein angiography helps in confirming the diagnosis of CSR.

Two patterns are seen :

  • Ink-blot pattern: It consists of small hyperfluorescent spot which gradually increases in size.
  • Smoke-stack pattern: It consists of a small hyperfluorescent spot which ascends vertically like a smoke-stack and gradually spreads laterally to take a mushroom or umbrella configuration.

Image below shows Ink-blot appearance.

The image below shows the following charectaristic appearances:

  • Image A - Cystoid macular edema - Petaloid appearance
  • Image B - Central serous retinopathy - Smoke stack pattern
  • Image C - Drusen - Stars in the sky appearance
  • Image D - Macular Ischemia - enlarged foveal avascular zone and capillary non perfused areas.

questions.text: A young man aged 30 years presents with difficulty in vision in the left eye for the last 10 days. He is immunocompetent, a farmer by occupation comes from a rural community and gives a history of trauma to his left eye with vegetative matter 10-15 days back. On examinations, there is an ulcerative lesion in the cornea, whose base has raised soft creamy infiltrate. The ulcer margin is feathery and hyphae. Branching septate hyphae were noted. There are a few satellite lesions also. Corneal scraping shows sickle-shaped macroconidia. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fusarium is the causative agent of the above condition.

  • The above clinical history is suggestive of mycotic keratitis, which is an invasive infection of the cornea usually following corneal trauma.
  • The causative agents of mycotic keratitis include many saprophytic fungi such as Aspergillus species, Fusarium, Curvularia, Alternaria, Acremonium, and Candida albicans.
  • However, in the above question, the causative agent is fusarium due to the presence of sickle-shaped macroconidia.
  • Fusarium is a hyaline filamentous fungi and may cause a range of opportunistic infections in humans.
  • In humans with normal immune systems, fusarial infections may occur in the nails (onychomycosis) and in the cornea (keratomycosis or mycotic keratitis).

questions.text: A lady was found to have the feature seen in image A, which is characteristic of a certain disease. On further investigations, she was found to have the immunofluorescence pattern seen in image B. Positivity of which of the following antibodies would predict a high risk of interstitial lung disease in her?
questions.solution:
Image A showing classical prominent perioral radial furrowing and microstomia and image B showing nucleolar pattern are suggestive of systemic sclerosis. Anti-Scl-70 positivity in this disease is useful in predicting those at high risk for interstitial lung disease.

Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features is seen in scleroderma. Initially, the fingers may be puffy and have nonpitting edema. The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly. Severe pruritus, vasospasm, and digital ulceration may be present. 

Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia (fish mouth appearance), perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma have dysphagia and gastroesophageal reflux at the level of the esophagus. The intense sclerosis of organs and primarily the fibrosis of the skin has devastating effects on the affected patients.

The nucleolar pattern (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus, representing antibodies against RNA) is most often seen in systemic sclerosis. 

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III are seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, which can have pulmonary manifestation as interstitial lung disease.

Other options:

Option A - Anti-U3-RNP (anti-fibrillarin) autoantibodies are associated with patients of Afro-Caribbean origin and can identify patients with SSc who are younger at disease onset and display a higher prevalence of myositis.

Option B - Anti-centromere antibody is most specific for CREST syndrome.
 
Option D - Anti-U1-RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

 

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is equal in both
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

 Anti centromere

questions.text: To assess the effects of the national population policy, data is being collected at the PHC level. You have been asked to submit data regarding the approximate magnitude of completed family size in the population under your PHC. Which of the following indicators will you calculate?
questions.solution:
The total fertility rate is an indicator of the approximate magnitude of completed family size.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: An elderly lady presented to the clinic following a head injury. She exhibited an unsteady drunk-like gait while entering the examination room. She also had nodding movements of the head and nystagmus. Which region of the cerebellum marked in the following image was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Area marked as 4 is most likely affected by the bleed, i.e., vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe).

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): This lobe is the oldest part of the cerebellum. It has vestibular connections concerned with equilibrium and eye movements. Therefore, in lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, patients will have gait ataxia, nodding of the head and axial body (known as titubation), and nystagmus.
  • Spinocerebellum: This is the region that receives proprioceptive inputs from the body as well as from the motor cortex. By comparing plan from the motor cortex with performance, it smoothens and coordinates movements that are ongoing.
  • Cerebrocerebellum: This is the newest part of the cerebellum. They coordinate with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements. Patients will have dysmetria, dysarthria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, or intention tremor in one or both extremities. 

Lesions in the cerebellum may present with the following symptoms:

  • Wide-based, drunk-like unsteady, stumbling gait, which is also called staggering gait
  • Ataxia - Defects in movement and coordination
  • Dysdiadokinesia - Inability to perform alternating movements (e.g. supination, pronation) at a fast pace
  • Dysequilibrium - Loss of balance
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor - This tremor is not present during rest, but is present during voluntary movements of limbs. The tremor increases when it reaches the target object of its movement.
  • Speech - Slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of the cerebellum

  Dorsal Spinocerebellum Ventral Spinocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) Vestibulocerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) 
Constituents Vermis (except the nodulus) The adjacent medial portion of the hemisphere The lateral portion of hemispheres Nodulus and flocculus 
Afferent (input) Somatosensory from the trunk, visual, auditory, and vestibular Somatosensory input from the limbs From the cerebral motor cortex, premotor, and somatosensory cortex  Vestibular input, visual input, somatosensory from the neck
Efferent (output) Via Fastigial nucleus to the medial descending system Via interposed nucleus to lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal systems Via dentate nucleus to motor, premotor and prefrontal cortex  To vestibular nuclei in the brain stem (direct projection)
Functions    

Maintains posture and helps in the execution of gross movements

It controls the interplay between agonist and antagonist group of muscles

 Controls the  distal muscles of the limbs (smoothens and coordinates movements) Planning the sequence of voluntary movements    

 Participates in maintaining equilibrium and posture

 

Controls ocular movements

It is responsible for regulating the stability of the head and body in space

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke’s criteria?

choices.text: Single positive blood culture for HACEK group is a major criterion
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion
Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.solution:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 1.4 Kg neonate is born at 29 weeks of gestation. The sonologist performing a neurosonogram is most likely to find an intracranial hemorrhage in the:
questions.solution:
Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in premature infants occurs in the gelatinous subependymal or germinal matrix.

In preterm infants, the germinal matrix (situated ventrolateral to lateral ventricles) is extensive and highly vascular which makes them prone to bleeding. Germinal matrix normally involutes during the third trimester.

Major neuropathologic lesions associated with very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants are intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and periventricular leukomalacia (PVL).

Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is characterized by focal necrotic lesions in the periventricular white matter.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about ethmoidal polyp?

choices.text: It is usually seen in children

questions.solution:
Allergy is the main etiological factor for ethmoidal polyp.

It is usually multiple, bilateral, and more common in middle-aged individuals.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: IUCD having the longest life span is _____________
questions.solution:
CuT 380 A has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paraguard): It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. Hence the Copper T-380A has been able to achieve superior contraception while maintaining a similar side-effect profile

The Copper T-380A has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the life span of the Copper T-380A.

The frame of the Copper T-380A is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

IUCD Life span
Cu T 380A 10 years
CuT 200 3 years
Multi loaded Cu 250  3 years
LNG IUS /Mirena

5 years
Progestasert 1 year
Nova-T 5 years

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with _______.
questions.solution:
Cryoglobulinemia is associated with hepatitis C infection.

Following Hepatitis C infection, there is an aberrant immune response leading to an immune complex formation containing hepatitis C antigens, polyclonal IgG specific to Hepatitis C, and monoclonal IgM rheumatoid factor, which triggers an inflammatory cascade results in Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis.

Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C, the presence of these cryoglobulins in serum leads to Cryoglobulinemia, which is characterized by cutaneous vasculitis, palpable purpura, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.

Important conditions associated with cryoglobulinemia are:

  • Hepatitis C
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Lymphoproliferative disorders

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Chaperones assist in protein folding. 

Chaperones are heat shock proteins. They bind to the short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids of an extended polypeptide. Thus, they shield the new polypeptide being synthesized from aggregating. This provides the polypeptide an opportunity to form an appropriate secondary structure.

When a protein is thermodynamically trapped in a misfolded dead-end form, chaperones can rescue the protein by unfolding their hydrophobic ends. Thus, they provide the protein a second chance to fold productively.

questions.text: Facial nerve gives out secretomotor fibers to all except
questions.solution:
Facial nerve gives out secretomotor fibers to lacrimal gland, submandibular gland and nasal glands (not parotid gland).

Secretomotor pathway to parotid gland:

Preganglionic fibers - originate in inferior salivary nucleus, pass through glosspharyngeal nerve, its tympanic branch, tympanic plexus and lesser petrosal nerve.

Relay ganglion:Otic ganglion.

Post ganglionic fibers: Pass through auriculotemporal nerve to reach the gland.

questions.text: α1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme ________.
questions.solution:
α1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

  • Lysosomal enzymes, if unchecked, can potentiate further inflammation by damaging tissues.
  • These harmful proteases, however, are normally controlled by a system of antiproteases in the serum and tissue fluids.
  • α1-antitrypsin is the prototype member of the serine protease inhibitor (serpin) superfamily of proteins.

Clinical correlate:

  • Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency (α1-ATD) is caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene located in the long arm of chromosome 14.
  • This genetic defect alters the configuration of the α1-antitrypsin molecule and prevents its release from hepatocytes.
  • As a result, serum levels of α1-antitrypsin are decreased, leading to low alveolar concentrations, where the α1-antitrypsin molecule normally would provide protection against proteases such neutrophil elastase.
  • The resulting protease excess in alveoli destroys alveolar walls and causes emphysema.

This is a NEET pattern MCQ.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given barium swallow image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and a characteristic bird-beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing).

In achalasia cardia, the lower esophagral spinchter (LES) is hypertensive and fails to relax appropriately in response to swallowing. Sphincter spasm and delayed emptying through LES are also seen. Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for establishing the diagnosis of esophageal achalasia.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis

100% failed peristalsis

Normal peristalsis

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal swelling. On examination, the testis is felt separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant, as shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a transilluminant scrotal swelling palpated apart from normal testes is suggestive of an epididymal cyst. 

An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to is the cystic degeneration of the epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates and has a Chinese lantern appearance.

The image shows the Chinese lantern appearance on transillumination:


It can be differentiated from a hydrocele, where the testis is not separately palpable.

Option A: Varicoceles present with dragging discomfort in the scrotum on standing and characteristic ‘bag of worms’ feel on palpation. 

Option C: Spermatocele is a unilocular transluminant retention cyst formed at the epididymal head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. Although transilluminant, the cyst does not have a Chinese lantern appearance.

Option D: Chyloceles are formed due to the rupture of lymphatic varix and the discharge of chyle into the hydrocele. Fluid rich in cholesterol is seen and the swelling is not transilluminant.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: Type I statistical errors occur if

choices.text: Null hypothesis is true but rejected
Null hypothesis is true and accepted
Null hypothesis is false but accepted
Null hypothesis is false and rejected

questions.solution:
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true is called as a type I error.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: Lennox Gastaut syndrome is characterized by

choices.text: EEG showing < 3Hz spike and wave discharge

questions.solution:
Lennox Gastaut Syndrome:

It is characterised by the triad:

  • Multiple seizure types
  • EEG showing slow  < 3Hz spike and wave discharges
  • Impaired cognitive function in most cases

questions.text: Screening for the patient for diabetic retinopathy with newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus type 2 should be done_____.
questions.solution:
• Since the natural course of diabetes mellitus type 2 has a long asymptomatic phase before the clinical diagnosis the disease, screening of retinopathy is done at the time of diagnosis whereas type 1 is usually detected early and hence the screening is recommended after 5 yrs
  • If the retina appears to be normal screening is repeated after a year.
  • It is repeated every 6 months in moderate non proliferative diabetic retinopathy whereas as every 3 months in case of severe non proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following protein is involved in the absorption of calcium in the intestine?
questions.solution:
• Ca2+ is transported across the brush border of intestinal epithelial cells via channels known as transient receptor potential vanilloid type 6 (TRPV6) and binds to an intracellular protein known as calbindin-D.
  • Calbindin sequesters the absorbed calcium so that it does not disturb epithelial signaling processes that involve calcium.
  • The absorbed Ca2+ is thereby delivered to the basolateral membrane of the epithelial cell, from where it can be transported into the bloodstream by either a sodium/calcium exchanger (NCX1), Ca2+ - Mg2+ ATPase, or PMCA1b
  • The overall transport process is regulated by 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol.

questions.text: Services provided by the establishment bearing the following logo is  ________
questions.solution:
The given logo is of Suraksha clinics, where color-coded STI/RTI (sexually transmitted infections/Reproductive tract infections) kits are provided.

The NACO has branded the STI/RTI services as Suraksha Clinic and it has developed a communication strategy for generating demand for these services.

The kits are:

  • Kit 1– grey, for urethra discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis
  • Kit 2 – green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3 – white, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4 – blue, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 5 – red, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 6 – yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7 – black, for inguinal bubo

Note: Anti retroviral therapy is given at ART centres under the National Aids Control Program- IV.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: You are asked to determine the sex of a person from the skeletal remains found on an empty site. Which of the following bones is most accurate for the same?
questions.solution:
The whole pelvis is the most reliable bone for sex determination.

Krogman’s degree of accuracy in sex determination from adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones and pelvis >95%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Long bones and skull - 90-95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Long bones alone – 80-90%

questions.text: What is the possible diagnosis for a patient with the ECG findings as shown below?
questions.solution:
The ECG image give shows diffuse ST-segment elevation characteristic of acute pericarditis.

Other options:

  • Inferior wall MI will show ST elevations in leads II, III, aVF
  • The ECG findings for pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade are:
    • Sinus tachycardia
    • Electrical alternans
    • Low QRS voltages
  • The ECG changes of hypothyroidism will include bradycardia with low voltage complexes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is diagnosed with gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally invasive gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic ultrasound is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally advanced gastric cancer.

Endoscopic ultrasound is the most sensitive investigation used to assess the preoperative local staging of gastric carcinoma. Five layers of the gastric wall can be visualized and the depth of invasion (T component of the staging) of cancer can be assessed with more than 90% accuracy. It can also show enlarged perigastric and celiac lymph nodes. In addition, it can identify liver metastases and assess gastric emptying. 

The limitation of this investigation is operator dependency and it may underestimate the lymph node involvement as normal-sized nodes (<5 mm) may harbor metastasis.

Other options:

Option A- MRI has a higher sensitivity in detecting liver metastasis of gastric carcinoma than conventional CT imaging.

Option B- CT scan of the abdomen/pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast is the best in preoperative staging of gastric cancer. However, it lacks sensitivity in detecting smaller lesions and is less accurate in T staging than endoscopic ultrasound.

Option C- Barium swallow is up to 75% sensitive in gastric tumors but has been replaced with endoscopic ultrasound in most centers as it is the gold standard for the diagnosis of gastric carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

Related Pearl: TNM staging of gastric carcinoma

questions.text: The space of Disse consists of all of the following except
questions.solution:
Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Browicz cells, are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. These are present in the lining the walls of the sinusoids, not the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse).

The space of Disse:

  • The perisinusoidal space (or space of Disse) is a location in the liver between hepatocytes and the liver sinusoid.
  • It contains the blood plasma.
  • Microvilli of hepatocytes extend into this space, allowing proteins and other plasma components from the sinusoids to be absorbed by the hepatocytes.
  • Some fat cells may also be present in the space of Disse.
  • The perisinusoidal space also contains hepatic stellate cells (also known as cells of Ito), which store fat or fat soluble vitamins including vitamin A).

questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity?
questions.solution:
Insulin levels are increased in obesity. It stimulates the synthesis of fatty acids and TAG and decreases the rate of lipolysis. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence their levels are reduced in obesity.

Hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance are consistent features of obesity. Insulin resistance is more strongly linked to intra-abdominal fat than to fat in other areas.

Adiponectin (Option D) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that is produced by adipocytes. It performs vital functions that are reduced in obesity - like, increasing insulin sensitivity and the inhibition of gluconeogenic enzymes. It also enhances fatty acid oxidation.

Insulin resistance in obesity occurs as a result of the following:

  • Insulin receptor downregulation
  • Increased FFA (free fatty acids) and capable of impairing insulin action
  • Intracellular lipid accumulation
  • Circulating peptides produced by adipocytes such as TNF-α, IL-6, RBP4, and resistin modify insulin action.

questions.text: These 2 molecules are _______ of each other.
questions.solution:
Mannose and galactose are epimers of glucose. But, galactose is not the epimer of mannose.

Isomers differing as a result of variations in configuration of the —OH and —H on carbon atoms 2, 3, and 4 of glucose are known as epimers. Biologically, the most important epimers of glucose are mannose (epimerized at carbon 2) and galactose (epimerized at carbon 4).

Since D-mannose and D-galactose differ in position of –OH group , at two carbon atoms (2nd and 4th ) , they will be diastereoisomers rather than epimers.

questions.text: All are true regarding the condition shown below except:

choices.text: It is more prevalent in women than in men
According to the CEAP classification, the above condition belongs to class C3
Their distribution indicates which superficial system is defective
The duplex ultrasound imaging has become the mainstay of investigation for this condition

questions.solution:
The above image shows presence of varicosities without edema, skin changes or ulcers. Class C2 indicates varicose veins and C3 indicates edema.

The prevalence of varicose veins is 25-30% in women, and 15% in men.

Distribution of varicosities indicate which superficial system is defective:

  • Medial thigh and calf varicosities indicate long saphenous incompetence
  • Posterolateral calf varicosities indicate short saphenous vein incompetence
  • Anterolateral thigh and calf varicosities indicate isolated incompetence of proximal anterolateral long saphenous tributary

Duplex ultrasound imaging has become the mainstay of investigation for varicose veins.

questions.text: Interstitial fluid volume can be calculated by using
questions.solution:
Interstitial fluid volume = ECF volume - Plasma volume

  • ECF is measured by radiolabelled sodium
  • Plasma volume is measured by radiolabelled albumin

So, radiolabelled sodium and radiolabelled albumin are used to measure the interstitial fluid volume.

  Volume Indicators
Total body water
  • 3H2O
  • 2H2O
  • antipyrine
ECF
  • 22Na
  • 125I-iothalamate
  • thiosulfate
  • inulin
ICF (Calculated as total body water − extracellular fluid volume)
Plasma volume
  • 125I-albumin
  • Evans blue dye (T-1824)
Blood volume

51Cr-labeled red blood cells

or calculated as

blood volume = plasma volume/(1 −hematocrit)
Interstitial fluid (Calculated as extracellular fluid volume − plasma volume)

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD?
questions.solution:
Hoarding behavior shows poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention.

Challenges posed by hoarding patients to typical cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) include poor insight into the behavior, low motivation, and resistance to treatment.

The most effective treatment for hoarding is a cognitive-behavioral model that includes:

  • Training in decision making and categorizing
  • Exposure and habituation to discarding
  • Cognitive restructuring.

questions.text: As per criteria recommended by WHO, presence of which of the following  in children between 6 months to 6 years should be considered as evidence of xerophthalmia problem in community:
questions.solution:
Xerophthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of corneal xerosis among children between 6 months to 6 years (high risk category) is more than 0.01%.

Prevalence Criteria For Determining The Xerophthalmia Problem in community:

Criteria Prevalence in population at risk (6 months to 6 years)
Night blindness >1%
Bitot’s spots  >0.5%
Corneal xerosis /Keratomalacia >0.01%
Corneal ulcer >0.05%
Serum retinol (<10mcg/dl) >5%

questions.text: What is the correct order of a family cycle?

choices.text: Formation, extension, complete extension, dissolution, contraction, complete contraction
Formation,contraction,extension, complete extension, dissolution, complete dissolution
Formation, contraction, complete contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution
Formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, dissolution

questions.solution:
The order of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: Factor X deficiency is associated with which of the following types of amyloidosis?
questions.solution:
Vascular amyloidosis causes vascular fragility that may lead to bleeding, sometimes massive, that can occur spontaneously or following seemingly trivial trauma.

In some cases , AL amyloid binds and inactivates factor X, a critical coagulation factor, leading to a life-threatening bleeding disorder.

The clinical manifestations of amyloidosis include:

  • Nephrotic syndrome, eventually renal failure
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Coagulation factor x deficiency (in AL amyloid)
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Macroglossia
  • Purpura
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
