questions.text: The part marked "x" in the image given below consists of all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The part marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: The image given below depicts the steps in glycogenolysis. Match the enzymes involved correctly.

choices.text: A - Phosphorylase, B - Glucan transferase, C - Debranching enzyme
A - Debranching enzyme, B - Phosphorylase, C - Glucan Transferase
A - Glucan Transferase, B - Phosphorylase, C - Debranching enzyme
A – Debranching enzyme, B – Glucan transferase, C - Phosphorylase

questions.solution:
A - Phosphorylase, B - Glucan transferase, C - Debranching enzyme.

Steps of glycogenolysis:

  • Step 1: There is breaking of alpha 1,4 linkages in glycogen by glycogen phosphorylase (rate limiting step)
  • Step 2: There is transfer of trisaccharide residue from one branch to another by glucan transferase, forming new alpha 1, 4 bond. Thus the alpha 1,6 branch point from where the residue is transferred, is exposed.
  • Step 3: Alpha 1,6 glucosidase hydrolyses this exposed branching point, leading to glucose 1 phosphate.
  • Step 4: Glucose 1 phosphate is converted to glucose 6 phosphate by phosphoglucomutase.
  • Step 5: In liver, phosphatase converts glucose 6 phosphate to glucose.

Related Pearl: Glycogenolysis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Lyme disease?

choices.text: Meningopolyneuritis or Bannwarth’s syndrome occurs in disseminated stage
The most common cardiac abnormality is a fluctuating degree of atrioventricular block
In the last stage chronic oligoarticular arthritis develops

questions.solution:
• Lyme disease is a tick borne fever caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

Stages of lyme disease:

  • Early infection:
    • stage 1 – Erythema migrans 
    • stage 2 – Disseminated infection. Meningitis accompanied by facial palsy and peripheral radiculoneuropathy(Bannwarth’s syndrome). Lymphocytic pleocytosis (~100 cells/μL) is found in CSF, often along with elevated protein levels and normal or slightly low glucose concentrations. 
  • Late infection – persistent infection 
  • Post- Lyme syndrome- chronic lyme disease 

Acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans: The late skin manifestation of Lyme borreliosis, has been associated primarily with B. afzelii infection. 

Diagnosis:

  • clinical if there is presence of erythema migrans
  • Serology

Management:

  • oral doxycycline for skin/mild disease
  • IV ceftriaxone for cardiologic/neurologic involvement

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking?
questions.solution:
The hemagglutination test is not based on the principle of antibody marking.

In tests based on the principle of antibody marking, the antigens or antibodies are labelled or marked with enzymes, fluorescent dyes, radioisotopes etc. In radioimmunoassay, fixed amounts of antibody and radiolabelled antigen react in the presence of unlabelled antigen. The labelled and unlabelled antigens compete for binding sites on the antibody. Thus, the concentration of the test antigen can be calculated from the ratio of the bound and total antigen counts using a standard dose-response curve. In immunofluorescence, fluorescent dyes are conjugated to antibodies or antigens. The labelled antibodies or antigens can then be used to identify antigens and antibodies, respectively. In ELISA, an adsorbing material - cellulose, agarose, polystyrene, polyvinvyl etc - is used to bind to either antigens or antibodies. 

When antibodies bind to antigens on the surface of red blood cells, the resultant clumping reaction is referred to as hemagglutination. It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing. The image below shows hemagglutination.

 

Note: If no hemagglutination occurs it means the patient’s serum has anti-haemagglutinin antibodies that bind to hemagglutinin and prevent the clumping reaction. This hemagglutination inhibition reaction is a method of detection of viruses and antiviral-antibodies and is used to make a diagnosis of influenza.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is popularly used in clinical anaesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Ulnar nerve stimulation at wrist is popularly used to assess the adequacy of neuromuscular blockade.

Neuromuscular blockade is measured using a peripheral nerve stimulator.

Nerve Response
Ulnar nerve Contraction of adductor pollicis
Facial nerve Contraction of orbicularis oculi
Posterior tibial nerve Contraction of flexor hallucis brevis

questions.text: Pott’s puffy tumor is
questions.solution:
Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone. It is a complication of frontal sinusitis.

An acute infection of the frontal sinus can cause osteomyelitis of the frontal bone. Suppurative material then breaches the frontal bone leading to subperiosteal abscess formation in the tissues of the forehead. Pus may form externally under the periosteum as a soft boggy swelling with a doughy consistency called Pott’s puffy tumor. It may spread internally causing subdural, epidural, and periorbital abscesses as well as secondary septic thrombosis of the dural sinuses. It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.

CT of the brain and paranasal sinuses is the most appropriate investigation. It can show the involvement of sinuses as well as intracranial or soft tissue spread of infection. 

Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, abscess drainage, and trephining of the frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, the removal of sequestra and necrotic bone may also be required. 

The images below show the clinical presentation and radiographic findings of the condition: red arrow - Pott's puffy tumor; blue arrow - intracranial spread

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding dapsone?

choices.text: It acts by inhibiting folic acid synthesis

questions.solution:
Dapsone has good oral absorption and it has a long half‐life, averaging 28 hours.

Dapsone or DDS (4,4‐diamino-diphenyl sulphone) is weakly bactericidal due to the inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase, which inhibits folate synthesis. It is a part of the multidrug therapy for leprosy.

Adverse effects include:

  • Mild hemolysis and anemia
  • Psychosis.
  • DDS syndrome or five-week dermatitis - occurs 5-6 weeks after starting dapsone. It may be fatal. It presents with: 
    • Exfoliative dermatitis
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Fever
    • Hepatitis. 

Uses of dapsone: 

  • Steroid sparing drug - long-term therapy for autoimmune blistering diseases
  • Adjuvant therapy - bronchial asthma
  • CNS-protective - seizure disorders, strokes, glioblastoma

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate presents with yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera. Which of the following may not be a cause of neonatal jaundice that appears after the first week of life?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis causes neonatal jaundice and manifests within the first 24 hours of life, not after 1st week.

Jaundice in the first 24 hours of life requires immediate attention and can be due to erythroblastosis fetalis, concealed hemorrhage, sepsis, or congenital infections, including syphilis, cytomegalovirus, rubella, and toxoplasmosis. Jaundice appearing on the 2nd or 3rd day of life is usually physiologic but also can be due to early onset breastfeeding jaundice and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (familial non-hemolytic icterus). Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 3rd day but within the 1st week of life can be due to bacterial sepsis, urinary tract infections or other infections like syphilis, etc.

Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 1st week of life can be due a number of conditions like breast milk jaundice, congenital atresia or paucity of bile ducts, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis, hemolytic anemia, enzyme deficiencies etc.

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. Continuation of breastfeeding exclusively resolves most of the cases.

The image below is of a schematic to approach to the diagnosis of neonatal jaundice:

questions.text: Barium study in a patient showed the Fleischner sign. The patient may be a case of _______
questions.solution:
The Fleischner sign on barium study is seen in Ileocecal TB. The thickening widely gaping ileaocaecal valve lips resulting in a patulous valve with narrowing of the terminal ileum is called the Fleischner sign. It is also called the inverted umbrella sign.

Signs of Tuberculosis intestine:

  • String sign
  • Gooseneck sign
  • Stierlein sign
  • Fleishner sign
  • Pulled up cecum

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: Transection at Level II marked in the below image with intact vagi results in
questions.solution:
Level II in the above image indicates mid pons.

Transection at mid pons level:

  • With vagi intact – Deep and slow breathing
  • With Bilateral vagotomy – Apneustic breathing (sustained inspiratory spasm, which is interrupted by brief and inefficient expiration)

questions.text: After assessing a patient with a traumatic head injury, a score of 3 was given for motor response. According to the Glasgow Coma Scale, what does the score indicate?
questions.solution:
Motor response of 3 indicates decorticate posture or abnormal flexion to pain stimulus.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text:
A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show the following findings. The blasts are positive for CD33. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 8.5 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000/Cumm

TLC: 52,000/Cumm with 83% blasts
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age. 

The peripheral smear shows blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules, Auer rods, and delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli. The blasts are positive for CD33. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients.

 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: Given below is ventriculography showing cardiac morphology in systole of a 65-year-old lady. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Myocardial stunning pattern does not match ECG
Histologically acute cases may show contraction band necrosis
Left ventricular apex is most commonly affected
ECG abnormalities don't include ST-segment elevation

questions.solution:
The image shows global ventricular dilation with basal contraction in a 65-year-old lady, which is strongly suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  ECG abnormalities including ST-segment elevation and elevated biomarkers of myocardial injury can be seen because Takotsubo mimics acute MI. 

Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken heart syndrome / Apical ballooning syndrome / Stress-induced cardiomyopathy)

  • It is a type of ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy caused due to elevated levels of catecholamines.
  • Also called broken heart syndrome due to its association with emotional duress.
  • The ventricle shows global ventricular dilation with basal contraction, forming the shape of the narrow-necked jar (takotsubo).
  • It is most common in postmenopausal women after sudden intense emotional or physical stress presenting as pulmonary edema, hypotension and chest pain.
  • Myocardial Stunning is a state where certain segments of the myocardium (corresponding to the area of major coronary occlusion) show forms of contractile abnormality. In takotsubo cardiomyopathy, while the ECG changes mimic a myocardial infarction, the left ventricular dysfunction extends well beyond the distribution of a specific coronary artery. Thus, the myocardial stunning pattern might not fully match the ECG.
  • Coronary angiography may be needed to rule out acute coronary occlusion.
  • Histologically acute cases may show microscopic areas of necrosis characterized by myocyte hypercontraction known as contraction band necrosis.
  • Subacute and chronic cases may show microscopic foci of granulation tissue and/or scar.
  • Treatment: No treatment has been proven beneficial. However, the following measures can be taken:
    • Nitrates for pulmonary edema
    • Intraaortic balloon pump for low output
    • Combined alpha+beta blockers if hemodynamically stable
    • Magnesium for arrhythmias related to QT prolongation

Ventriculography showing cardiac morphology in systole in a patient with takotsubo cardiomyopathy - global ventricular dilation with basal contraction. A takotsubo – a pot (tsubo) for catching an octopus (tako).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiparous women >40yrs, presenting with abdominal mass (free from adnexa) and myometrial cysts on MRI, point towards a diagnosis of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years. Patients generally present with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and sometimes dyspareunia. On examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. 

Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) reveals a salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

Other options:

Option A: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the endometrial lining (uterus). They usually present as dysmenorrhea and lower dull abdominal pain. Vaginal examination reveals a tender fixed retroverted uterus. They can be managed medically (oral contraceptives, aromatase inhibitors, etc)  and surgically (if failed medical management). Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is performed in advanced cases.

Option C: Leiomyoma (fibroid) is the commonest benign tumor arising from the uterus. They present as abnormal uterine bleeding, infertility, and abdominal pain. On bimanual examination, the uterus is enlarged and the mass moves with the cervix. It can be managed medically (mifepristone or newer progesterone) and surgically. A myomectomy is performed for large fibroids with significant symptoms.

Option D: Endometrial hyperplasia can be simple, glandular, or atypical. They are seen in women with estrogen excess states like obesity, PCOD, or on tamoxifen therapy. They usually present as abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).

questions.text: Which is the last fontanelle to close?
questions.solution:
The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close. It closes at around 18-24 months of age.

Fontanelles of the skull:

Fontanelle  Location Closes at 
Anterior

Between frontal and parietal bones

Junction marked by bregma

 18-24 months 
Posterior Sagittal and lambdoid sutures 2-3 months
Sphenoid Pterion 2-3 months
Mastoid/Posterolateral Intersection of temporal, parietal, and occipital bones. 6-18 months (average 12 months)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the casualty with complaints of recurrent episodes of syncope and cramping of his left arm. Symptoms mostly occur during his evening badminton practice sessions.  Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Due to occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery
Distal pulse of the affected side is feeble
CT angiography is used to visualize retrograde blood flow

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of subclavian steal syndrome. In subclavian steal syndrome, the first part of the subclavian artery is occluded.

Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by the presence of stenosis in the first part of the subclavian artery either due to atherosclerotic changes or emboli. It leads to reversed flow in the vertebral artery causing cerebral ischemia.

Symptoms include dizziness, syncope on arm exercise. Occasionally, distal pulses in the arm of the affected side are found to be feeble.

Investigations include duplex ultrasonography, CT, and MR angiography.

It can be treated by angioplasty, stenting or by extra-thoracic subclavian bypass.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the assessment of body fat?
questions.solution:
Breslow's staging is used for the staging of malignant melanoma, not for the assessment of body fat.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density

questions.text: A 2-year-old malnourished child presents with loose stools. The child has symmetrical edema, weight/height <70% of expected and height/age < 85% of expected. Management of this child involves ___________

choices.text: Continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves for the next 2 hours
Use low sodium ORS for rehydration 5ml/kg every 30 min for first 2 hours
Give 5ml/kg of ringer lactate IV if unconscious

questions.solution:
The above child has severe malnutrition. Management should involve the use of low sodium ORS for rehydration 5 ml/kg every 30 min for first 2 hours.

WHO Classification:

Parameter  Moderate malnutrition Severe malnutrition
Symmetrical edema No Yes
Weight/height (wasting) -2 to -3 S.D(70 to 79% of expected) < -3 S.D (<70%)
Height/age(stunting) -2 to -3 S.D(85 to 89%) < -3 S.D (<85%)

Treatment:

  • Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock.
  • Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours orally or NG tube.
  • Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hour. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink. Feed-in the other alternate hour.
  • Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy.

Treatment of hypoglycaemia in malnutrition:

  • If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL), or a feed or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue-whichever is the quickest.
  • If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40

questions.text: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.solution:
Leiden mutation is a single nucleotide mutation that occurs in factor V. This is named after the city in The Netherlands where it was discovered.

Of the inherited causes of hypercoagulability, point mutations in the factor V gene and prothrombin gene are the most common. 

Related Pearl: Hypercoagulable states

Primary (Genetic Conditions):

  • Mutations in factor V (Most common)
  • Antithrombin III deficiency
  • Protein C or S deficiency
  • Fibrinolysis defects
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Allelic variations in prothrombin levels
  • Mutations in the methyl tetra hydro folate (MTHF) gene

Secondary (Acquired Conditions):

  • Prolonged bed rest or immobilization
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Tissue damage (Surgery, fracture, burns)
  • Cancer
  • Myocardial infarction, Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

questions.text: Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Thrombocytosis is not associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). On the contrary, thrombocytopenia is seen.

APS is an autoantibody-mediated condition that is characterized by arterial thrombosis, venous thrombosis, and recurrent fetal loss. These autoantibodies bind to the phospholipids present on the endothelial cells and activate coagulation and thrombus formation.

Important manifestations of venous thrombosis are:

  • Deep vein thrombosis of legs
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Livedo reticularis
  • Cerebral venous thrombosis

Important manifestations of arterial thrombosis are:

  • Stroke, transient ischemic attacks
  • Retinal artery thrombosis
  • Myocardial ischemia
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis- due to the vegetations formed by platelet fibrin microthrombi
  • Leg ulcers, gangrene of the digits

Important obstetric manifestations are:

  • Preeclampsia
  • Recurrent fetal loss
  • Premature birth

Important hematological abnormalities are:

  • Thrombocytopenia- occurs due to increased platelet aggregation and thrombus formation 
  • Coombs positive hemolytic anemia- seen when autoantibodies attack red blood cells
  • Thrombotic microangiopathic syndromes- thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

questions.text: Which organism is implicated in causing the following clinical picture?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a typical ‘slapped cheek appearance’ seen in erythrema infectiosum. It is caused by parvovirus B19.

Erythrema infectiosum

  • Fifth disease
  • Caused by Parvovirus B19
  • Peaks at 5 – 15 yrs
  • Prodromal phase
    • Mild fever
    • Mild URI
  • Rash – Slapped cheek appearance
    • First on face
    • Spreads rapidly to trunk and proximal extremities as macular rash
    • Undergoes central clearing to give lacy pattern
  • Other options
    • HHV - 6 causes Roseola Infantum – Sixth disease (HHV-6B)
    • Paramyxovirus includes parainfluenza and mumps virus – causes lower and upper respiratory infection in children and painful enlargement of salivary glands respectively
    • EBV – causes Infectious mononucleosis

questions.text: All of the following procedures can be used in FIGO  staging of cervical cancer  as per FIGO revised 2018 report except _____________
questions.solution:
The FIGO Cancer Report 2018 no longer mandates any biochemical investigations or investigative procedures in staging of cervical cancer.

FIGO staging was based mainly on clinical examination with the addition of certain procedures that were allowed by FIGO to change the staging. However, in 2018, this has been revised by the FIGO Gynecologic Oncology Committee to allow imaging and pathological findings, where available, to assign the stage.

Other options:

  • The revised staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e. ultrasound, CT, MRI, positron emission tomography (PET), to provide information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.
  • In case a surgical specimen is available or where image-guided fine- needle aspiration cytology has been done, the pathologic report is an important source for accurate assessment of the extent of disease.
  • Diagnosis of Stage IA1 and IA2 is made on microscopic examination of a LEEP (loop electrosurgical excision procedure) or cone biopsy specimen.

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?
questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone acts through aquaporin channel 2.

ADH binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.

Clinical note: Lithium, which is often used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene. 

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: A boy presents with breathlessness to the hospital. He gives a history of leg pain over the calf for a few days, for which he sought massaging from his mother, after which he developed breathlessness. Which of the following findings on the ECG would suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism for this patient?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis leading to pulmonary embolism.

The specific abnormality in ECG seen in pulmonary embolism is

The S1 Q3 T3 sign:

  • S wave in lead I
  • Q wave in lead III
  • Inverted T wave in lead III

S1Q3T3 is highly specific but not sensitive (meaning it is not always present).

Instead, the most common abnormality in pulmonary embolism is right ventricular (RV) strain and ischemia, which is depicted on an ECG as T-wave inversions in leads V1-V4.

questions.text: Pontogeniculooccipital spike is characteristic of the _____ phase of sleep?
questions.solution:
Pontogeniculo-occipital spike (PGO) is characteristic of REM sleep. There is an occurrence of large phasic potentials arising from cholinergic neurons in pons, which pass rapidly to the lateral geniculate body and then to the occipital cortex.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1P0 woman presents for her first prenatal visit late in her first trimester of pregnancy. She complains of persistent vaginal bleeding, nausea, and pelvic pain. Physical examination is notable for gravid uterus larger than expected for gestational age. Fetal heart sounds are absent. Which of the following is most likely to be true?

choices.text: Ovaries can be cystic from multiple theca lutein cysts
p57 is strongly expressed in the tissues involved
β – HCG levels will be less than normal

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a molar pregnancy.

Ovaries can be fuller and cystic from multiple theca lutein cysts. It is likely due to ovarian overstimulation by excessive hCG levels. These theca-lutein cysts regress following pregnancy evacuation. Occasionally a larger cyst may undergo torsion, infarction, and hemorrhage.

In a molar pregnancy the β–HCG levels will be higher than normal.

The thyrotropin-like effects of hCG frequently cause serum free thyroxine (T4) levels to be elevated and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels to be decreased.

p57 is used for immunohistochemical staining. It is a nuclear protein whose gene is paternally imprinted and maternally expressed. This means that the gene product is produced only in tissues containing a maternal allele. Because complete moles contain only paternal genes, the p57 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.

questions.text:
Which of the following cannot cross the placenta?
  1. Iron
  2. Albumin
  3. Immunoglobulin M
  4. Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
Albumin and IgM cannot cross the placenta.

High molecular weight substances such as proteins (e.g., albumin, IgM, IgA) cannot cross the placenta, except IgG.

Substances which can cross the placenta are as follows:

Iodine

Calcium

Vit C

Note: Maternal hormones like insulin, steroid hormones, and thyroid hormones cross the placenta very slowly, and only in amounts enough to support fetal development. However, calcitonin and parathormone do not cross the placenta.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the vital layer of a slow sand filter?
questions.solution:
The vital layer of a slow sand filter is also called the zoogleal layer, Schmutzdecke, or the biological layer.

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about erysipelas?

choices.text: Rarely extend to deeper soft tissue
Occurs most commonly on the trunk

questions.solution:
Erysipelas occurs more commonly on face and extremities, rather than the trunk.

Erysipelas:

  • Sharply demarcated infection of superficial lymphatic vessels with Streptococcus pyogenes, which is abrupt in onset with fiery red swelling. 
  • Indurated, well defined margins, usually along nasolabial fold, with rapid progression and intense pain.
  • Rarely extend to deeper soft tissue.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Cutaneous infections/diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Direct infections of skin or subcutaneous tissue

  • Cellulitis
  • Impetigo
  • Ecthyma, Erysipelas
  • Vulvovaginitis
  • Perianal infection
  • Streptococcal ulcers
  • Blistering distal dactylitis
  • Necrotizing fasciitis

Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

Tissue damage from circulating toxin

  • Scarlet fever
  • Toxic‐shock‐like syndrome
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

Skin lesions due to allergic hypersensitivity to Streptococcal antigens

  • Erythema nodosum
  • Vasculitis

Skin disease provoked or influenced by Streptococcal infection (mechanism uncertain)

  • Psoriasis, especially guttate forms
  • Kawasaki disease

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of
questions.solution:
The given slide is pathognomonic for measles. This is a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

The lymphoid organs typically have marked follicular hyperplasia, large germinal centers, and randomly distributed multinucleate giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

These are pathognomonic of measles and are also found in the lung and sputum.

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is__________
questions.solution:
The molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin–Johnson syndrome is ABCC2.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in ABCC2. ABCC2 codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette. A defect in this gene leads to the mutation of the multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. This in turn leads to a defective transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile. 

It presents with abdominal pain, mild icterus, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Biopsy shows black liver due to an accumulation of epinephrine metabolite.

Conditions causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia are summarised in the table below:

Dubin-Johnson syndrome Rotor syndrome
Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
The absent function of multiple drug-resistant proteins (MRP-2) Defects in anion transport
Black liver on biopsy (due to accumulation of epinephrine metabolite) No abnormal liver pigmentation.
Normal levels of coproporphyrin in urine Increased levels of coproporphyrin in urine 
The gall bladder is not visualized on oral cholecystography The gall bladder is visualized on oral cholecystography

Important diseases and their molecular defects:

ATP7A  Menke’s disease 
ATP7B  Wilson disease 
CFTR  Cystic fibrosis 
SERPINA 1  α-1 antitrypsin deficiency 
ABCC2 (MRP2 protein defect)  Dubin Johnson syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not a TNF alpha inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Anakinra is a recombinant, non-glycosylated form of human interleukin 1A. It is approved for use in rheumatoid arthritis and for cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes (CAPS).

Infliximab, etanercept, and golimumab are TNF alpha inhibitors (options a, b and d). Adalimumab & Certolizumab are other TNF alpha inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Apolipoprotein E4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac chambers is enlarged in mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially?
questions.solution:
Left atrium (LA) is the first cardiac chamber to get enlarged in mitral stenosis (MS). It is due to the pressure overload of LA. It can be appreciated on the lateral and left anterior oblique views.

Other radiographic changes seen in MS are straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette, posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA, and Kerley B lines due to distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema.

Severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension leads to enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and right atrium. Left ventricle remains unaffected in isolated MS.

questions.text: What is the type of hypersensitivity involved in multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is a Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction with specificity of pathogenic T cells to antigens in myelin (e.g.myelin basic protein).

Principal Mechanisms of Tissue Injury:

  • Inflammation mediated by TH1 and TH17 cytokines
  • Myelin destruction by activated macrophages

Clinicopathologic manifestations is due to demyelination in CNS with perivascular inflammation.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include
questions.solution:
A partial mole is not a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm (GTN).

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is the term used to describe a group of tumors due to abnormal trophoblast proliferation. Malignant forms of GTD are termed gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution?

choices.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.solution:
Adulteration of food is included under the concurrent list.

The legislative section of the seventh schedule is divided into three lists:

  • Union list - a list of 100 items on which the parliament has exclusive power to legislate
  • State list - a list of 61 items on which the state government has exclusive power to legislate
  • Concurrent list - a list of 52 items on which both central and state governments have the power to legislate

questions.text: A patient shows FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted, under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted is classified as severe COPD under GOLD classification.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

  GOLD Stage   Severity   Spirometry
I Mild FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted
II Moderate FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted
III Severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted
IV Very severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: Which of the following metals can be detected even in conflagrated human remains?
questions.solution:
Arsenic can be detected even in conflagrated human bones. Hence, it is possible to detect poisoning by arsenic even when the body has been burnt for a long time.

Arsenic is volatile but much of the arsenic in bones is converted into arsenates, which are non-volatile. 

In suspected cases of poisoning by arsenic, all the available ashes and burnt bones should be preserved for chemical analysis.

questions.text: The prolonged use of which of the following tocolytic agents leads to bone thinning?
questions.solution:
The FDA (2013) warned against prolonged use of magnesium sulfate given to arrest preterm labor due to bone thinning and fractures in fetuses exposed for more than 5 to 7 days.

This was attributed to low calcium levels in the fetus.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the orthopedician with complaints of painful swelling below the knee joint.  An X-Ray was obtained which is given below. Which of the following is the preferred treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray showing an expansile, eccentric, multiloculated lytic lesion, at the end of a long bone with a soap-bubble appearance suggests a giant cell tumor (GCT) or osteoclastoma. The treatment of choice for this condition is extended curettage and bone grafting.

Giant cell tumor is a benign but locally aggressive tumor seen involving the metaphysis and /or the epiphysis of long bones, as seen in the image, in young adults of age 20-45 years and rarely teenagers less than 20 years.

Although an aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is also a benign, locally destructive, eccentric multiloculated lytic tumor that can present with a similar radiographical picture in any age group (most commonly in adolescents), it is confined within the metaphysis of the long bones, unlike GCT, thus ruling it out in this case. On MRI a fluid sign can be seen.

The following is an x-ray image of the knee showing ABC confined to the metaphysis of the long bones:

An ABC is treated by extended curettage and grafting with a bone graft substitute (option B).

GCT is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. It presents with complaints of swelling and vague pain and Sometimes, the patient can presents for the first time with a pathological fracture because of the lesion.

Important x-ray features of a GCT:

  • Eccentric, solitary lytic lesion
  • In epiphysis and metaphysis
  • Expansile- expands overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - due to the trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing the lytic lesion, giving it a loculated appearance.
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor
  • No calcification

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue.

The treatment of choice for GCT is by

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting (Option A).
  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like the distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiotherapy can be used for vertebral tumors
  • Additional supportive therapy such as cryotherapy, when used reduce the reccurence rate.

 

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Giant cell tumor, adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance / Shepherd's

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors (chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn, punctate or comma-shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Stippled or Punctate calcification

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors (osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment / Trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double-density fluid levels and intra-lesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Vertebral metastasis

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.solution:
In the clinal scenario of a 55-year-old woman with third-degree uterine prolapse, the ideal management is vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair. 

Uterine prolapse is the descent of the uterus from its normal position which usually occurs due to laxity of ligaments that offer support, seen often due to childbirth, aging, or trauma. The uterine descent is clinically categorized into:

  • First degree:  the external os remains above the vaginal introitus
  • Second degree: The external os protrudes below the vaginal introitus but the uterine body remains inside the vagina 
  • Third degree (Syn: Complete prolapse): The uterine, cervix, body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus
  • Procidentia involves prolapse of the uterus with the entire vagina everted.

The patient usually presents with a sense of heaviness in the pelvic region with lower back discomfort. Based on the structures involved the patient can additionally have urinary symptoms (like incontinence and urgency), bowel disturbances (constipation and tenesmus), or sexual discomfort during intercourse.

Symptomatic uterine prolapse is managed surgically with different procedures based on the profile of the patient. Conservative management is done for old asymptomatic women with mild degree prolapse. 

A vaginal hysterectomy is recommended for patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • >40 years of age 
  • Have completed their families
  • Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function

Other options:

Option A: Fothergill repair or Manchester operation is a procedure done to preserve the reproductive function and vaginal prolapse with supravaginal cervix elongation. It initially involves preliminary curettage with low amputation of the cervix. After Mackenrodt's ligament is plicated,  anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy are performed.

Option B: Sling operation (Purandare's operation) is indicated in congenital or nulliparous prolapse without cystocele. The procedure involves the extraperitoneal passage of rectus sheath strips joined to the anterior surface of the cervix by silk sutures.

Option D: Shirodkar procedure is a type of abdominal sling surgery done in young women to retain menstrual and reproductive function. It involves using a sling to fix the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia. 

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulin levels are decreased in Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Serum IgM levels are decreased in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. However, IgG is usually normal and paradoxically IgA and IgE are often elevated.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes. Normally, WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus helps in cell adhesion, migration, and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells. In WAS, there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood resulting in defects in cellular immunity. 

The clinical features of WAS are recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) expression in blood cells. IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Ig A and Ig E levels are high. Reduced-sized platelet is a typical feature of WAS. 

The image given below shows eczema seen in WAS.

questions.text: Giant cell (Hecht's) pneumonia is due to?
questions.solution:
• Hecht's pneumonia, also known as giant cell pneumonia, is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition.

The postmortem examination (autopsy) shows multinucleated giant cells lining the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs.

questions.text: For hypertrophic non-union following a fracture, the most appropriate treatment would be __________
questions.solution:
In cases of hypertrophic non-union following a fracture, stabilization alone has the potential to induce union.

Non-union following a fracture occurs when the healing process fails to progress, resulting in a failure to unite. There are two primary types of non-union:

  • Hypertrophic - where callus formation is present but does not bridge the fracture site
  • Atrophic - characterized by minimal or no attempt at callus formation

For hypertrophic non-union without deformity, conservative treatment using functional bracing or rigid fixation alone (internally or externally) can promote union. However, in cases of atrophic non-union, fixation alone is insufficient, requiring the excision of fibrous tissues in the fracture gap and sclerotic bone ends, followed by the application of bone grafts around the fracture.

questions.text: What does number 2 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?

choices.text: Diagnosed hypertensive subjects not on treatment

questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the "rule of halves", which shows the distribution of hypertension in the community. The number 2 in this diagram denotes normotensive subjects.

The rule of halves is a way of depicting the iceberg phenomenon seen in hypertension. It depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries are aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The circles marked by numbers in the given diagram correspond to the following parts of the population:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Rivaroxaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. They represent a new class of oral anticoagulant drugs that do not require monitoring.

This group of drugs inhibit factor Xa in the final common pathway of clotting [conversion of Prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa)]. They are given as fixed doses and have a rapid onset of action.

Oral direct factor Xa inhibitors are indicated in:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: Bilateral posterior iliac horns shown below are characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Bilateral posterior iliac horns ("Fong prongs")  are characteristic of nail-patella syndrome. They are seen due to exostoses arising from the posterior aspect of the iliac bones.

Nail-patella syndrome: Also known as Fong disease or osteo-onychodysostosis. It may also be referred to as Österreicher-Turner syndrome or Turner-Kieser syndrome.

It is a rare autosomal dominant condition which results from symmetrical mesodermal and ectodermal abnormalities. The key feature is absent/hypoplastic nails from birth. Individuals may have flexion contractures and recurrent knee dislocations.

Diagnostic radiographic findings include:

  • Absent/hypoplastic patellae (with a tendency of recurrent dislocation)
  • Hypoplasia of the radial head or capitulum (leading to subluxation/dislocation)
  • Bilateral posterior iliac horns ("Fong prongs")
  • Protuberant anterior iliac spines

questions.text: The incidence of which of the following complications has been reduced by performing chorionic villous sampling after 10 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
• CVS (chorionic villous sampling) was associated with limb reduction defects and oromandibular limb hypogenesis. These were found to be associated with procedures performed at 7 weeks of gestation.
  • When CVS is performed at more than or equal to 10 weeks of gestation as it is commonly done today, the incidence of limb defects does not exceed the background rate of 1 per 1000.

questions.text: Radiotherapy is indicated when the spread of angiofibroma extends to which site?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is used for intracranial extension of disease when tumour derives its blood supply from the internal carotid system. Recurrent angiofibromas have also been treated by radiotherapy.

Conformal radiotherapy in extensive juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) or intracranial extension provides a good alternative to conventional radiotherapy regarding disease control and radiation morbidity.

questions.text: The drug efavirenz inhibits
questions.solution:
The drug efavirenz inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase. It is an NNRTI.

There are five classes of drugs in combination can be termed antiretro viral therapy (ART), combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) or highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

Antiretroviral drugs are classified by the phase of the retrovirus life cycle that the drug inhibits.

Antiretroviral drugs:

Nucleoside/Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors:

Mechanism: Nucleoside/Nucleotide analogs which inhibit reverse transcriptase.

Zidovudine

Didanosine

Stavudine

Zalcitabine

Lamivudine

Abacavir

Tenofovir disoproxil, Tenofovir alafenamide,

Emtricitabine

Nonnucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors: 

Mechanism: Inhibit reverse transcriptase by binding to an allosteric site of the enzyme.

Nevirapine

Efavirenz

Delavirdine

Etravirine

Rilpivirine

Protease Inhibitors:

Mechanism: Block the viral protease enzyme necessary to produce mature virions upon budding from host membrane.

Saquinavir

Indinavir

Ritonavir

Nelfinavir

Amprenavir

Lopinavir

Atazanavir(1st line)

Fosamprenavir

Tipranavir

Darunavir(1st line)

Entry Inhibitors:

Mechanism: interfere with binding, fusion, and entry of HIV -1 to cell by blocking a target.

Maraviroc works by targetting CCR5, a coreceptor located on human helper T-cells

Enfuvirtide

Maraviroc

Integrase Inhibitors:

Mechanism: Inhibit the viral enzyme integrase, which is responsible for the integration of viral DNA into the DNA of the infected cell.

Raltegravir

Elvitegravir

Dolutegravir

questions.text: The presence of serpiginous ulcers on esophageal endoscopy indicates ______
questions.solution:
CMV lesions appear as serpiginous ulcers in an otherwise normal mucosa, particularly in the distal esophagus.

questions.text: A young boy presented with a cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that gives the appearance of a frog’s belly. A ranula usually resolves spontaneously.  

A plunging ranula is a mucus retention cyst. It has mucus collecting below the gland and perforating through the mylohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.  

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

Related Pearl: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

  • It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid
  • Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.
  • Conditions with cross fluctuation are :
    • Plunging ranula
    • Bilocular hydrocele
    • Compound palmar ganglion
    • Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

questions.text: To calculate the positive predictive value of a new screening test for breast carcinoma, what will you use for the denominator?
questions.solution:
The denominator for the calculation of the positive predictive value of a screening test is true positives + false positives.

Positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test actually has the disease. It is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. However, it is affected the most by prevalence.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: What is the basis for the formation of omphalocele?

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.solution:
Omphalocele is protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring. It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity, which results in non-closure of the umbilical ring. .

An omphalocele may contain stomach, liver, and intestines. And these contents are enclosed in a sac.

Omphalocele is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of α-fetoprotein.

Note: In gastroschisis, there is an absence of a membranous sac and is paraumbilical.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: Receptor for inverse stretch reflex_____
questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ is the receptor for inverse stretch reflex (refer figure).

The Golgi tendon organs, unlike the spindles, are in series with the muscle fibers; therefore, they are stimulated by both passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle.

The degree of stimulation by contraction of muscles is much greater than that caused by the stretching of muscles.

Muscle contraction → Ib fibers from the Golgi tendon organ excite an inhibitory interneuron that releases inhibitory mediator glycine → hyperpolarization (inhibition) of α motor neurons → muscle relaxation.

Related Pearl: Summary of Muscle Reflexes

(knee-jerk)

Monosynaptic

Muscle is stretched

Ia

Contraction of the muscle

Golgi tendon reflex/ Inverse stretch reflex (clasp-knife)

Disynaptic

Muscle contraction

Relaxation of muscle

Flexor-withdrawal reflex (after touching a hot stove)

Polysynaptic

Pain

II, III, and IV

Ipsilateral flexion; contralateral extension

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

questions.solution:
The fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca laterally.

The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia lying immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament. It extends from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) superolaterally and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

Attachments:

  • Medially, its fibres insert by a broad attachment into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, behind the conjoint tendon. 
  • Laterally, its fibres fan out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliaca without bony attachment to the iliac spines. 

Clinical note: It is considered as an important landmark in laparoscopic hernia surgeries.
